—My question is to the Minister for Resources and Energy. The minister is well aware of the importance of renewable energy sources. Will the minister advise what measures the government is taking to support research and development for renewable energy sources? How does support for renewable energy research and development under the Howard-Fischer government compare with that of previous governments?

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —I would like to thank Senator Sandy Macdonald for that question. The government recognises that renewable energy has a very important role to play in our overall energy mix, and the government is committed to encouraging an expanded commercially viable renewables industry.

answer.para: In November 1997, as part of the $180 million five-year program, the Prime Minister announced a major new package of measures to encourage innovation in the renewable energy sector. These measures include $21 million for a renewable energy innovation investment fund on a two to one funding basis with industry; $30 million of concessional loans and grants for the development and commercialisation of strategically important renewable energy technologies—this represents a huge increase on the $4.8 million over four years spent by Labor; and $10 million for a showcase fund to support leading edge renewable energy projects in areas such as tidal power, solar thermal power and photovoltaics. This is an action oriented program for the renewable energy sector which goes much further than simply encouraging research. It will stimulate innovative technologies and wealth creating business. It will provide many new real jobs for Australians and new export industries to help address Labor's legacy of foreign debt.

The Howard government has established a target for electricity retailers and other large electricity buyers to source an additional two per cent of electricity from renewable energy sources by the year 2010. This target will provide significant opportunities for the use of solar, biomass, wind and other emerging technologies. It will also provide its own stimulus for renewables R&D.

Never before has the electricity industry been so well placed to look at cost effective markets for renewable energy technologies. Already, over 120 megawatts of electricity capacity has been installed to supply electricity using municipal and agricultural wastes. Many of the newly formed electricity distributors are actively marketing green energy and promoting installation of renewable energy systems.

As a result of these initiatives by the Howard government, the level of support for renewables will be considerably greater than that provided by any previous government. Funding for renewable energy in Labor's last budget was estimated at $7.5 million. In 1998-99, the first year of the Prime Minister's climate change package, Commonwealth funding of renewable energy R&D is estimated at $16 million. This represents a massive increase in support for renewable energy R&D and includes measures not even contemplated by Labor. There is little wonder that Labor has nothing to say about renewable energy. Labor failed to produce an integrated renewable energy strategy in government, as in so many other areas. It has done nothing in opposition. It is totally policy free.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment, and it concerns the Port Hinchinbrook development and the spill of thousands of tonnes of dredge spoil. talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —I suppose senators within the protection of this place can defame professional people, if they so choose, but it does not actually advance the debate particularly far. The honourable senator would, of course, be aware that I answered a similar question in relation to Professor Sanger's qualifications. It was asked of me by Senator Faulkner some months ago, and I refer him to the answer I gave then. He will not find the question particularly helpful, but he will find within the answer the response to a number of the matters he raises.

answer.para: It is important that the event that occurred at Hinchinbrook, which was a slump of one of the spoil ponds during dredging last week, did not have the dire consequence as has been suggested by some. In fact, the information that I have to date—it is to be further investigated—is that the material was not acidic at all. Therefore, the advice that I have received from the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is that it is not believed to have caused any environmental damage to world heritage values.

I understand that the slump that occurred was in fact repaired within three hours, and we have arranged for GBRMPA to inspect it with an appropriately qualified engineer this week to see whether any further long-term work needs to be done. But I remind the honourable senator also that, as of late last year, we were advised that these ponds had been built according to best engineering standards, that they were doing their job properly and that, therefore, there was not a concern. We do not expect any significant damage to result therefrom but, nevertheless, we want to have the pond walls tested again to ensure that such a slump will not occur again.

It is good news to the extent that there has not been any damage caused, which is consistent with the high engineering requirements of this project—some might say more demanding engineering requirements than any coastal development in the history of Far North Queensland. Nevertheless, because it is such an important issue, we will have the wall tested again to see whether any further action should be taken.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. Minister, will you provide details of any information provided by GBRMPA from their further investigations to the Senate to enable us to draw our own conclusions? Could you also confirm the section in relation to my previous question about Keith Williams choosing Professor Sanger personally? Have not hundreds of scientists written privately to express their horror at this development since it was first proposed? Are not good scientists who are national and even global experts in their field being bullied into silence by threats of legal action or even of losing their jobs? Are not people who are not known experts in the field being used to comment on this development in a desperate attempt to legitimise what the developer and the federal and Queensland governments are doing to destroy the world heritage values of the channel? Are you not aiding and abetting Australia's biggest science cover-up and forcing a process where experts either are not listened to, have their work twisted, or are too intimidated to talk publicly?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —I have to say I have rarely heard so much nonsense. This project, as I said, is subject to the most demanding engineering requirements that we are aware of for this type of development. talker.role: Environment

answer.para: The major issue to be resolved in the establishment of an intercountry adoption program with China is the automatic recognition of Chinese adoptions by Australia. There is no consistent legal mechanism in the states and territories for the automatic recognition of overseas adoptions. Under current arrangements, a child entering Australia after being adopted overseas comes under the provisions of the Immigration (Guardianship of Children) Act until such time as the adoption is formally recognised by a state or territory court. Whilst that has been a satisfactory arrangement for other countries, Senator Harradine, the view of the Chinese government is that it is insufficient and that they need an automatic recognition of the adoption process that has taken place in China.

The matter could have been resolved through the ratification of The Hague convention by both Australia and China, as parties to the convention are obliged to recognise adoptions made in accordance with its arrangements. But as China is not expected to ratify the convention for some time, we have looked at other ways to progress the matter. We have agreed that the Australian laws should now be amended to allow for the automatic recognition in Australia of foreign adoptions from prescribed countries where a bilateral agreement has been made with Australia.

We will introduce this bill into the parliament in the next session, Senator Harradine. I trust that the parliament might be prepared to deal with it in the one session so we can put it into effect. The effect will be that the arrangement under the bilateral agreement will, in addition to the law, have the effect of recognising the adoption that had taken place in China. There will then be in place an arrangement for ongoing adoption of children from China under this process. It has been frustratingly slow, but I am pleased that progress is now being made. talk.start.para: —Last Thursday, 2 April, Senator Murphy asked me a question in regard to the Anti-Dumping Authority's inquiry into wood-free coated paper from a number of countries. He also asked me a supplementary question. I seek leave to incorporate the detailed answer given to me by the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs to both the original answer and the supplementary. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.

Minister [Parer] can you tell the Senate whether the Minister for Customs will reject the ADA's finding that the amount of paper dumped by Belgium, France, the Netherlands, Switzerland and Taiwan is negligible because, according to the ADA, it constitutes only seven per cent of the total Australian import volume? Will the Government instead commit to imposing anti-dumping duties upon the relevant companies upon the grounds that no level of dumping is acceptable when people's jobs are at risk?

This question relates to the Anti-Dumping Authority's Inquiry into woodfree coated paper from a number of countries. The Anti-Dumping Authority announced on 1 April, by Notice published in the Financial Review, that it had terminated the inquiry into coated paper from Belgium, France, the Netherlands, Switzerland and Taiwan as the total volume of exports from these countries was no more than 7 per cent of the total Australian import volume over the period of the period.

Under subsection 7B(3) of the Anti-Dumping Authority Act 1988, the Authority must terminate an inquiry if it finds that dumped exports from a particular country represent less than three per cent of total imports of the goods under inquiry or if exports from countries, whose individual share of imports are less than three per cent, when combined are seven per cent or less.

The Authority has found that dumped imports of coated paper from Belgium, France, the Netherlands, Switzerland and Taiwan, when combined, represent no more than seven per cent of total imports. In fact, they only represent about three per cent, which equates to some two per cent of the Australian market.

If the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs were to act as suggested by Senator Murphy, he would be acting contrary to legislation enacted by this Parliament and contrary to Australia's obligations under the WTO Dumping Agreement. Clearly, in view of both of these points, the Minister should not and cannot so act.

In 1994 Australia, along with many other countries, became a signatory to the WTO Agreements. One such Agreement under the banner of the WTO is The Agreement on Implementation of Article VI of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade 1994—commonly referred to as `the Dumping Agreement'.
Article 5.8 of that Agreement states:
'. . . an inquiry shall be terminated immediately in cases where the authorities determine that the volume of dumped imports. . . is negligible'.

The Agreement goes on to say that, in this context, `negligible' means that the volume of dumped goods from a particular country is less than 3 per cent of total imports of those goods into a Member country or, where several countries have less than 3 per cent of such imports, their combined share does not exceed 7 per cent of imports.

Article 18.4 of the Dumping Agreement requires that signatories shall take all necessary steps to ensure that their domestic laws and regulations conform with the provisions of the Agreement. In response to this Article the then Government introduced a Bill into this Parliament in 1994 to amend the relevant Acts dealing with anti-dumping matters. The Bill was passed by both Houses and the amended legislation took effect from 1 January 1995.

One such amendment was the introduction of a new section into the Anti-Dumping Authority Act 1988 section 7B. Subsection 7B(3) states that the Anti-Dumping Authority must terminate a dumping inquiry if it finds that the volume of dumped goods is negligible. The definition of `negligible' is to be found in section 269TDA of the Customs Act 1901 but, for practical purposes, is essentially identical to that contained in the Dumping Agreement as explained above.

If the Authority finds that the criteria applying under subsection 7B(3) of its Act apply in a given case, the Parliament has decided that the Authority is to terminate the inquiry with respect to the exporters in question. My advice is that such termination is mandatory (the Authority has no discretion in the matter) and has not issued powers to the Minister to overturn the Authority if it so acts.

Against this background, it is obvious that the Minister cannot overturn a decision by the Authority to terminate an inquiry. If he were to do so, he would clearly be acting contrary to law, contrary to the Dumping Agreement and in contempt of this Parliament.

These were amendments proposed by the then Government, the Labor Party, and if Senator Murphy has a problem with the fact that the Authority must terminate the inquiry then he should ask his colleagues, Senators Schacht and Cook who were the relevant Ministers at the time.

Let me reiterate that the legislation is quite clear and unambiguous on the division of power for terminating inquiries and where the Authority is authorised to terminate, the provisions are mandatory. The Minister has no authority in this matter.

There is another feature of both Australia's legislation and the Dumping Agreement that would prevent the Minister imposing measures on the basis suggested by Senator Murphy. Before the Minister can impose dumping duties on future exports of a particular product, he must be satisfied—in accordance with subsection 269TG(2) of the Customs Act 1901—that dumping has caused or threatens to cause material injury to the Australian industry producing like goods, and that there may be future exports that may be dumped. This requirement has been reflected in Australia's anti-dumping legislation for decades and is also contained in the Dumping Agreement.

There is no scope for the Minister to impose anti-dumping measures on the ground that `no level of dumping is acceptable' as suggested by Senator Murphy. This is not an adequate basis in law, nor in terms of Australia's international obligations, for imposing such measures.

Madam President, I ask- a supplementary question. Minister, I thank you for the part answer that you gave, but you did not really address the question with regards to whether or not the government will reject the ADA findings and impose any duties. I guess that is part of the problem. I wonder whether or not the Minister is going to tell the workers at the Wesley Vale paper mill in Tasmania that the loss of their jobs on the basis of a result of a so-called negligible amount of dumped paper is an acceptable price to pay for the Government's failure to introduce legislation to improve the anti-dumping laws of this country. Is this just not another example of the long list of the non-core promises for which Australians again must pay?

On 25 February the Ministers for Industry, Science and Tourism and Customs and Consumer Affairs announced that there would be a comprehensive reform of Australia's anti-dumping and countervailing duty mechanisms. Under the new arrangements, interim duties can be imposed after 60 days, the time taken to reach a final finding will be reduced to 155 days and the Anti-Dumping Authority will be abolished. These reforms will give Australia the fastest anti-dumping arrangements in the world. Draft legislation to implement the new arrangements is expected to be introduced into Parliament in the May budget session with a commencement date of 1 July 1998.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.
On 26 June 1997, on the motion of Senator Ferris, the following matter was referred to the Committee of Privileges:
That the questions raised in the letter dated 26 June 1997 from the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority be referred to the Standing Committee of Privileges.

The questions involved the appearance at a public hearing by Mr John Elliott after Mr Elliott had made a written submission relating to an inquiry by the joint committee on the operations of the National Crime Authority. One member of the Committee, Senator Stephen Conroy, sought to question Mr Elliott using as a basis for his questioning a document which was challenged by Mr Elliott's legal adviser as being improperly obtained. As a consequence of the NCA committee discussions, the document from which he quoted was expunged from the Hansard record of proceedings.

Following the public hearing, the NCA committee raised questions on which it sought what was in effect an advisory opinion from the Senate Committee of Privileges. The questions, in order, asked by the NCA committee and the answers which the Committee of Privileges now gives, are as follows:

(a) whether Senator Conroy's rights in relation to his capacity to question a witness appearing before the Committee were infringed in relation to the Committee's proceedings in Melbourne on 12 June 1997.
The answer to that is:

Having concluded that none of the evidence given by Mr John Elliott in his written submission of 4 June 1997, and his oral presentation of 12 June 1997, should have been received by the National Crime Authority Committee (see answers to questions (b) and (c) below), and that as a consequence no members of that committee should have been permitted to question him, the Committee of Privileges must also conclude that Senator Conroy's rights as a member of the committee were not infringed.
The next questions are:

(b) whether a member of the Committee is prohibited from asking questions of a witness in respect of evidence given to the Committee by that witness covered by either of the elements of subsection 55(2) of the National Crime Authority Act 1984 or that relates to material covered by section 51 of the Act.
and

(c) whether the Committee was prohibited from receiving some or all of the evidence of Mr John Elliott in Melbourne on 12 June 1997, because of the provisions in subsection 55(2) of the National Crime Authority Act 1984, or because the evidence related to material covered by section 51 of the act.
The answer to that is:

The Committee of Privileges has concluded that, given the nature of Mr Elliott's evidence, both written and oral, before the NCA Committee, that committee was so constrained by subsection 55(2) of the National Crime Authority Act 1984 that it was prohibited from receiving any such evidence. It follows that committee members were similarly prohibited from asking questions of him in respect of the proscribed evidence. It also follows that committee members generally are prohibited from either receiving, or asking questions in respect of, evidence given by a witness covered by either of the elements of subsection 55(2) of the National Crime Authority Act 1984.

The committee has further concluded that section 51 of the National Crime Authority Act 1984 had no application to the proceedings of the National Crime Authority Committee on 12 June 1997, and has no general application to that committee's proceedings.
The question under (d) was:
(d) whether, as a consequence of the consideration of point (c), some or all of the evidence Mr Elliott gave to the Committee should be expunged from the transcript of evidence.
Our answer to that is:

While this question is ultimately a matter for the NCA Committee to determine, the Committee of Privileges suggests that expungement of any evidence taken by that committee on 12 June 1997 is impracticable, ineffectual and undesirable.

In reaching these conclusions, the Committee of Privileges points to the difficult relationship between the NCA Committee and the National Crime Authority since the act came into operation because of the constraints imposed by section 55(2). It observes that the present NCA Committee might not have faced such difficulties as have led to the present conclusions if recommendations of its predecessor had previously been acted upon.

The Committee of Privileges notes that the NCA Committee has tabled in the House of Representatives and is about to table in this chamber a report on the general terms of reference to which I have referred; it hopes that the statutory constraints which have caused such difficulty for the National Crime Authority Committee since its establishment will be promptly addressed. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

It deals with a total of eight agreements, two of which are on the topic of sea dumping of wastes. The other two multilateral agreements are about Australian involvement in amendments to the International Whaling Convention the Truce Monitoring Group on Bougainville and.

The four bilateral agreements deal with amendments to a double taxation agreement, amendments to a health services agreement, an extradition treaty and an agreement on judicial assistance and cooperation. The so-called London Convention will be replaced by the 1996 Protocol when sufficient countries have expressed consent to be bound by it. talk.start.para: —On behalf of Senator MacGibbon and the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present a report entitled Australia and ASEAN: Managing Change , together with submissions, transcript of evidence and minutes of proceedings.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report, to incorporate Senator MacGibbon's tabling statement in Hansard and to continue my remarks later.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report of the joint committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade—Australia and ASEAN: Managing Change —is its first in this area since 1984. I thank Margaret Swieringa for her work in its preparation.

As all senators are aware, a profound change has occurred in the region. The optimism of the early part of this inquiry, that ASEAN economies would continuously grow and prosper, has been tempered by the currency crisis which began in Thailand in July last year and has since affected, in varying degrees all of east Asia. The crisis has brought expectations of growth back to more standard levels, has highlighted the complexities of achieving sustainable development and has emphasised the importance of institutional development and good governance in that process. It has thrown down a challenge to ASEAN—its slow consensual style, its decisiveness and its cohesion.

The crisis also has altered the strategic outlook for the region, with the strategic uncertainty inherent in the reorientation of great power politics at the end of the cold war exacerbated by the possible threat to internal political stability in some states. The decline in economic circumstances is likely to worsen the broader security threats of transborder crime, illegal movements of peoples, the outflow of refugees, disputes over environmental degradation and competition for resources. Many of these are issues of concern already on the agenda of the ASEAN regional forum—an undeveloped avenue for regional consultation, whose importance is recognised and supported by the committee.

The inquiry took a considerable body of evidence in the early part of 1997 which stressed the oppor tunities in the region for Australian trade. Australia's natural, geographically-based connection to the `fastest growing region in the world' appeared to ensure the expansion of Australian export trade. The report deals in some detail with an analysis of the bilateral and sectoral trade relationship between Australia and the region and including regional trade liberalisation under AFTA and APEC.

The committee does not underestimate the seriousness of the current problems or the challenges they pose. These are not simple or painless matters for countries to resolve. The committee was able to take some evidence on the possible causes of the problems and on the response of the IMF and regional governments. The committee endorses the Australian government's readiness to participate in the IMF packages offered to the republic of Korea, Thailand and Indonesia. However, with such rapidly developing circumstances over recent weeks, our analysis is simply a snapshot. The seminar held in parliament house on 19 march and the seminar report will elaborate on our preliminary findings, particularly in respect of Indonesia.

The report remains optimistic about long term trends. It concludes that `despite the recent economic difficulties in the region, which are likely to result in depressed demand for Australian exports in key ASEAN markets, the prospects for continued growth in two way trade in the long run remain solid.'

However, in other spheres of our relationship with the region, some concerns were expressed. Many witnesses stressed the importance of paying more attention to the social, cultural and political relationships between Australia and regional countries. Areas of weakness were perceived in bilateral tensions over political style or the differences in values, particularly human rights, declining cultural representation or the paucity of expenditure on regional cultural activity.

Strongly criticised was the withdrawal of our most natural communication with the region through the closure of radio Australia. The committee strongly urges a reconsideration of the decision to close the Cox peninsula transmitters.

The committee believes that: ASIAN studies and student exchanges, both of ASIAN students coming to Australia and of Australians studying in Asia be enhanced and improved; and that literary, artistic and cultural exchanges with the region be increased.

To this end, the committee endorses the new international cultural council and hopes that it will be adequately funded and resourced to achieve real advances in regional understanding and appreciation.

Development assistance to the region will need to be reassessed in the light of the economic downturn. The crisis has focused particular attention on the need for institutional strengthening and the development of regulatory and accountable systems. Many of the recommendations of the report are directed to strengthening capacity and institutions in both the financial and political spheres.

In its 30th anniversary year, which ASEAN began as a self-confident, independent and forceful regional voice, the economic crisis has provided a challenge to the association's ability to retain its cohesion and to act decisively in the interest of the whole region. This report lays down some of these challenges.
I commend the report to the senate.
Debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of Senator Ferris and the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I present a report entitled Third Evaluation of the National Crime Authority , together with submissions and transcript of evidence received by the committee.
—by leave—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

I would like to firstly thank the committee secretariat for wading their way through a substantial amount of documentary evidence, Hansard , controversy—it was a very difficult report to prepare for the secretariat staff. I want to put on record my congratulations to them for their report. I would like to congratulate members of the committee for persevering at times under extreme duress, particularly when some witnesses gave their views of the committee at varying stages, but everybody maintained a degree of decorum you would expect.

To the substance of the report, there are a number of recommendations in the report which I endorse. The majority of the recommendations were endorsed by a cross-section of all parties in the chamber. The report calls for a number of increases in the powers of the authority to deal with search warrants but at the same time keeps a balance between the civil liberties aspects.

Probably the most controversial of the recommendations is to do with the powers of the committee itself, and that is what I would really like to speak about the most today. The committee report stresses the difficulties that the committee has in effectively supervising the National Crime Authority. What you have is a committee that is completely constrained by the act from actually being able to supervise the activities of the authority. This is a necessity and a balance that, when the legislation was passed—and this chamber debated it at length, I understand—was to protect the NCA from interference. At the same time, it has led to a committee that is unable to properly do its job.

Governments of both persuasions have baulked at giving the committee more access and greater power. This is not a party political speech; this is to say that the committee, in the past, has been treated with a fair degree of disdain by governments from both sides. But in the light of what has transpired over the last few years and allegations that have mounted about the proper or improper behaviour of the NCA, the committee has been unable—it does not have the resources; it does not have the support—to effectively monitor the NCA.

What we have seen is governments of both persuasions standing there and saying, `Yes, we have an oversight body. We have the joint parliamentary committee. It looks after the NCA. You can sleep well at night, citizens.' Members of the committee strongly felt that this furphy should be put to rest. This committee cannot effectively monitor the NCA. Ironically, it is probably the one thing I am in agreement on with John Elliott. There are not many things on which I and John Elliott agree.
Senator Ferguson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —He is the Carlton President for a start. John Elliott has stressed that the committee is incapable of supervising the NCA. Ironically, I agree with him. It is nigh on impossible to get an answer on a controversial issue out of the NCA. I am told that the current management of the NCA is much freer in what they are willing to discuss than previous managements of the NCA. The question of whether you can brief the parliamentary committee on the activities of the NCA is a difficult issue. The NCA is involved in many important investigations, particularly in the world of drugs. It is doing as good a job as it can within the funding levels that it has.

speech.para: Both sides have been responsible—again, this is a non-partisan position from the committee—for reducing funding levels for the NCA. It has gone too far. If this organisation is to be able to do its job properly both in corporate fraud and in the fight against the drug lords, then you absolutely have to be prepared to give this organisation more money. It has many runs on the board when it comes to breaking drug rings. It needs resourcing. The committee was told about many instances where the NCA is not able to pursue obvious cases that come to light because their funding is constrained. This is a fault of both governments. As I say, I am not here saying that the Labor Party, the Liberal Party or the coalition are responsible. This is something that has to be non-partisan.

There is a need for greater funding for the NCA which is not tied. We have a situation at the moment where they have been given extra funding, and that is worthy, but it is tied to individual issues. They must be able to operate and monitor, and take advantage of increased funding to continue the pursuit of all sorts of organised criminal activities. Organised criminal activity is getting more and more sophisticated. We are hampering the NCA's capacity to fight it by its lack of support overall in its recurrent funding, its base level funding. talk.start.para: —by leave—I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the sixth annual meeting of the Asia Pacific Parliamentary Forum held in Seoul, the Republic of Korea, between 7 and 10 January 1998. I seek leave to make a few remarks with respect to this.

talk.start.para: —The report I have just presented records the outcomes of the sixth annual meeting of the Asia Pacific Parliamentary Forum which was held in Seoul, the Republic of Korea, from 7 to 10 January of this year. The Australian delegation was very capably led by Mr Bill Taylor, the member for Groom, and by Mr Harry Jenkins, the member for Scullin, the deputy leader. Other members were Paul Neville, the member for Hinkler, and myself. The delegation was given strong support in Korea by the Australian Ambassador, Mr Mack Williams, and by the counsellor at the embassy, Mr Richard Ryan. We were very grateful for this and for the excellent support provided before our departure in the form of high quality briefing material provided by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of the Parliamentary Library.

speech.para: The APPF is now a well-established regional organisation to which Australia has made a strong contribution since its beginnings at the meetings in Singapore and Canberra in 1991. Previous annual meetings have been held in Japan, the Philippines, Mexico, Thailand and Canada. The organisation has evolved its own corporate practices and procedures over this time. The underlying principles have remained, however, and have been strengthened at each annual meeting. These principles include a commitment to frank and constructive dialogue between parliamentarians from the 26 member countries representing over 45 per cent of the world's population.

I can inform the Senate that there certainly were free and frank exchanges of views at Seoul. At the sixth annual meeting the agenda covered a wide range of matters, many of which were the subject of consensus resolutions after the debate. These included: the fourth ASEAN regional forum; the Korean peninsula situation; Cambodia; APEC's Vancouver meetings; the Asian currency crisis; regional economic cooperation; the environment and other global issues such as energy, education, drugs, terrorism, cultural exchanges and corruption; the Ottawa convention; and Myanmar.

Members of the Australian delegation participated fully in all plenary sessions and I believe made a significant contribution. We worked well together in the executive committee, the plenary and also the working committee to develop the joint communique. Australia also nominated with Japan, Korea, Peru and Thailand to serve on the APPF's technology working committee, which will be working towards, amongst other things, the establishment of an Asia Pacific interparliamentary open information network by 2001. This presents a particular challenge and an opportunity to create an effective, open and secure mechanism for legislative interchange and the information exchange between member parliaments and individual parliamentarians. As an early development, the APPF's website is already established and links most parliaments, albeit superficially at this stage.

This was my first experience of an APPF meeting, but I know you, Madam Acting Deputy President, the President and your predecessors have given strong support to the APPF over the years. This year's meeting at Seoul was pleased to accept Australia's invitation to host the eighth annual meeting in Sydney in January 2000. This was widely seen as a further example of Australia's commitment to this important region.

talk.start.para: —The committee is considering the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2] . The minister has foreshadowed government amendments Nos 66 to 76 relating to the registration test—that is, topic 17.

—In this debate on the registration test, I am being asked to support a physical connection test for native title rights. I am being asked to be amongst the first group of politicians in Australia to dismiss the spiritual and cultural imperatives of indigenous Australians; I will not be part of this. If Senator Harradine wishes to inflict another dose of cultural genocide upon Aboriginal people, let him do that with the support of the Prime Minister and Senator Minchin. He will certainly not get my assistance to ease his conscience on that matter.

speech.para: Both the government's provisions and Senator Harradine's amended physical connection test are utterly disrespectful to Aboriginal people. They are caving in to a racist paradigm which seeks to define `real' Aborigines. They ignore the shame and hurt that is felt and experienced by the stolen generations. It is one more kick in the teeth to the victims of an appalling modern day holocaust. Senator Harradine has a clear choice: his amendment does not have the numbers from the non-government parties in the Senate; either he sticks to his 1997 position, which maintains the Mabo spiritual and cultural connection test, or he supports the Howard government's despicable physical connection test.

I have no doubt that Senator Minchin at some stage soon will attempt to discredit my argument by claiming that I do not understand the legislation and that I am not aware there is a two-stage process for native title claims. So I would like to put on record that I do understand that this physical connection test applies to the registration track of the proposed two-track process. I do understand that it requires at least one member of the native title claim group to have or have had a physical connection to the land claimed. I am also aware that the regulations refer to a physical connection. I believe those regulations should be disallowed, but there is a big difference between those regulations and this legislation.

The regulations do not prevent someone from exercising statutory native title rights. Both Senator Minchin and Senator Harradine will claim that a physical connection test is needed to provide workability to exclude multiple claims. Let me make it clear now that the physical connection test has nothing to do with workability. In fact, most of the so-called problem areas associated with overlapping claims such as the goldfields involve claimant groups who would pass even the government's draconian physical connection test.

This is not about workability; it is a direct attack on the integrity of Aboriginal culture and should be exposed as such. There is already a host of changes to the registration test which ensure that it will be far more difficult to gain registration for the purposes of gaining the right to negotiate. This physical connection test—and Senator Harradine's lawyers have said this to me—is about satisfying that racist sentiment in society that says that the indigenous people of this continent are only real Aborigines if they are still living in the bush and that, somehow, those who have moved or have been moved to places other than their traditional lands are inferior in terms of native title rights. That is what the physical connection test is about. I for one refuse to give way to this Hansonite view.

It is totally insulting for Senator Minchin to say, as he has on many occasions, that this test is necessary to establish that only bona fide claimants obtain the right to negotiate. In effect, Senator Minchin is saying that those who have been denied the ability to maintain a physical connection for whatever reason are not bona fide Aboriginals. I must say that I am ashamed to be part of a parliament where such views are expressed. I am sure that in years to come people looking back at these debates will be shocked and appalled by such views, just as millions of Australians are currently shocked and appalled by such a notion.

In essence there are two sets of reasons why the physical connection test should be opposed. The first set of reasons is associated with the short-term effects on the native title process. There are those legitimate claimants who may well achieve a determination of native title based on the Mabo test who will miss out on the right to negotiate. As Aboriginal people have stated on many occasions, native title is next to useless without the right to negotiate. For Senator Minchin or Senator Harradine to claim that this physical connection test is somehow justifiable because it applies only to those wishing to claim the right to negotiate is disingenuous in the extreme.

I do not know how many registrations will be knocked out by this test, but neither does Senator Harradine nor Senator Minchin. The mere fact that there is a distinct likelihood that winnable claims will be denied the right to negotiate is sufficient for it to be rejected outright. Let us not forget, either, that the new registration regime will apply retrospectively to potentially knock out existing claims already in the right to negotiate process.

There are very serious cultural and legal problems associated with a test involving parenthood, such as that which is proposed by Senator Harradine. During the committee hearings on the bill, Professor Marcia Langton said:

The issue of apical ancestry in Aboriginal belief systems is one of belief, particularly because of such things as, say, in some Aboriginal societies there is the taboo on speaking the names of the dead.

I hope somebody is listening to this because, if we are talking about people having to establish this in a court or before they get to any legal process, and if you are dealing with cultural issues where people are unable to speak the names of the dead, then you have a problem built in.

It is not always going to be easy to establish that deceased parents had a physical connection to the land when, in some Aboriginal communities, it is actually against traditional laws to even speak the names of parents who have passed away, let alone establish a prima facie case before a tribunal, especially a native title tribunal which, under the changes proposed by section 109(2) of this bill, will not be able to take into account cultural and customary concerns which are deemed to unduly prejudice any other party to the proceedings.

The other serious, and I would say fatal, flaw in Senator Harradine's amendment is the definition of `parent'. In many Aboriginal communities, a person's parent is not their biological mother or father but another member of the clan group. How does Senator Harradine, or anyone else, see the definition of `parent' being applied in a culturally appropriate manner? Again, how will it be defined by a tribunal and a Federal Court which have been restricted in their ability to take cultural and customary concerns into account?

What about when a member of the stolen generation has been adopted? In this case their legal parent may well be a European Australian, and as such they will be excluded from being a person who can qualify as a native title claim group for the right to negotiate even if their biological parent, from whom they were stolen, had maintained their cultural and spiritual connection to the land. This amendment is the height of cultural insensitivity. It will see international derision heaped upon this country. It is a cruel joke played on the Aboriginal people of this continent.

The second set of reasons why we will be opposing any form of physical connection test is perhaps even more important than the more technical issues I have already raised. It is the message it sends to the entire community about the nature of Aboriginal land rights. For the first time, this parliament will be saying that a former physical connection is necessary for a native title right to be enjoyed. How is that going to make Aboriginal and Islander people who do not pass the test feel about themselves and their cultures?

I am sure that Senator Minchin will soon invoke his mantra that only one member of the claim group needs to be able to demonstrate a physical connection for a group to be registered, but what does this effectively do to establish a hierarchy of Aboriginality within Aboriginal communities? Those people in a community who cannot pass the government's test will know that they have not been classified by the government as the types of Aborigines who can qualify their claim group for the most important native title right available to indigenous communities—the right to negotiate—no matter what their history of oppression, no matter what irrepressible connection to country and culture those Aboriginal people have. This is really offensive stuff.

What sort of country is willing to sell Aboriginal culture and spirituality for all it is worth when it comes to marketing for tourism or the Olympics, yet relegates it when it comes to actually providing substantive native title rights? People in this chamber who even contemplate a physical connection test of any kind have to take a really hard look at themselves and their commitment to understanding and reconciling with the Aboriginal people of this land.

This issue highlights how totally inappropriate it is for a group of white parliamentarians—and I include myself—to be making laws about native title rights when there is no possible way that we can understand the complex nature of Aboriginal communities and their relationship with country. We run an enormous risk of making some horrendous mistakes. It is clear that the only native title rights which we should be passing into law are those which have the unadulterated and informed consent of indigenous Australians—and you could hardly say that of this bill.

I know that we have been critical of the ALP over the last few days, but I acknowledge that Senator Bolkus abhors racial discrimination and that he reflects the views of rank and file members of the Labor Party who abhor racial discrimination. I therefore trust that the ALP will also reject Senator Harradine's amendment. It may be a marginal improvement on the government's measures, yet it falls far below the standards of racial discrimination to which Senator Bolkus and the Labor Party ascribe. The ALP has promised to maintain its position of 1997. Its rejection of Senator Harradine's amendment is central to keeping that promise.

I indicate again that the Greens (WA) will not be supporting Senator Harradine's amendment, so it will not be a matter in this particular case of going from what is a preferred option to whatever happens to be left. In fact, we ask Senator Harradine to withdraw the amendment to avoid bringing further shame upon this parliament. I repeat that Senator Harradine now has a clear choice either to support a test which recognises spiritual and cultural connections or to be relegated to historical infamy by supporting the government agenda.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I think it might be easier, given that in previous debates there has been some confusion about what we are dealing with, if we deal with the blocks as indicated and then work through them—that might be easier for everybody. Therefore, I will formally move amendments 66 to 69 so we can deal with them. I would be happy to deal with the lot at once but, if the committee prefers, in terms of dealing with government amendments first I suggest that we do it in blocks so that everybody knows what we are dealing with. The government amendments are all interrelated. If the committee finds it easier to do it that way, I am happy to oblige. I move:

speech.para: (66) Schedule 1, item 9, page 94 (after line 18), at the end of section 30, add:

para.inline: Registered native title rights and interests

speech.para: (3) For the purposes of this Subdivision, the registered native title rights and interests of a native title party are:
(a) if the native title party is such because an entry has been made on the National Native Title Register—the native title rights and interests described in that entry; or
(b) if the native title party is such because an entry has been made on the Register of Native Title Claims—the native title rights and interests described in that entry.
Note about Schedule 1, item 9: The heading to section 30, page 93 (line 21) is altered by adding at the end "etc. ".
(67) Schedule 1, item 9, page 95 (line 10), omit "determined or claimed", substitute "registered".
(68) Schedule 1, item 9, page 106 (line 11), omit "determined or claimed", substitute "registered".
(69) Schedule 1, item 9, page 106 (lines 27 and 28), omit "determined or claimed", substitute "registered".

talk.start.para: —Could I just clarify where the government amendments are that we are talking about?
—They are government amendments Nos 66 to 69 on page 17 of the sheet headed `Revised 2'. It is schedule 1, item 9, section 30 on the registration test.
—Madam Chair, it would help the committee if when indicating amendments the number of the document could be mentioned.

—While people are looking for the description of the amendments, I will just indicate that amendment No. 66 goes to the question of native title parties. It allows for a bit more flexibility in respect of the registering on the title of those parties which have passed the registration test. We have no problem with that. Amendment No. 66 does that. Amendments Nos 67 to 69 are amendments to sections 31 and 39 and, in a sense, they are consequential amendments. They remove the words `determined or claimed' and replace them with the word `registered'. They pick up some of the concerns of native title claimants about the earlier test being a bit prohibitive. The opposition sees these amendments as beneficial and will support them.
—I wish to indicate that I have looked at those provisions and I have put a tick beside them, so I do not see any reason for delaying the committee.

—I need to speak to these amendments and to indicate the Democrats' position. This section of the government's amendments is perhaps the most troubling example of what the 10-point plan is really about. When we last debated this bill in December, I spoke extensively on the issue of spiritual connection to land, not just for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, islander Australians, but for all of us. I want to make some reference to that speech again.

speech.para: I must say that, in my experience as a clergyman, when people speak about the significance of spirituality there is no doubt that for many people that is the fundamental way in which they describe their being. That is so often true of Aboriginal and other indigenous people. For that reason, we see the registration test as a trapdoor through which the government would like native title to fall. It is a hurdle that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders will have to jump to have their rights dealt with in a fair and equitable way. What is not very often understood, though, is that native title is the self-evident, manifest reality of their daily existence. Indigenous Australians do not need courts or tribunals to convince them of the existence of native title.

The whole reason that native title exists in both common law and in statutes is because white people do not, in the main, recognise indigenous reality. Native title is an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander insurance policy against the repeat of the dispossession, dishonesty and genocide of the past. To gain that insurance, Aborigines are expected to pay too high a premium—for that is what the registration test is.

I turn to Senator Harradine's amendment. This amendment requires that native title claimants have to prove not only that they had an association with the land but also that they have had regular physical access to the land. There is the qualification of an additional generation with the physical connection and we recognise that as an improvement, but the Democrats could not support this amendment. We believe that the physical connection test is flawed in morality and in law. The Democrats do not accept that, in moving this amendment, Senator Harradine has given enough consideration to issues such as those raised in the recent report on the stolen generation whereby many Aboriginal people were forcibly removed from their families and continuous physical relationship with the land was deemed impossible. I add that, with successive governments in Queensland of all complexions, it was government policy to move people from one end of the state to the other.

I will give a couple of examples. One of the communities which has been spoken about on a number of occasions in this chamber is the community at Mapoon on western Cape York. Part of the reason that the Mapoon people are having such a struggle in resolving native title is that, even amongst themselves, there is confusion about who really belongs to that community, so a distinction has been made between historical and traditional people. The traditional people are those who can trace their ancestry back many generations, whereas historical people are people whose grandparents, perhaps, or great-grandparents were moved to Mapoon from many other parts of northern Queensland. For them Mapoon is also their land, but a distinction is made between those who can trace their ancestry back many generations and those who have an ability to trace their ancestry back only two or three generations.

This whole issue is compounded by the fact that, in the early 1960s, the people were driven out of Mapoon. Some of them went to Thursday Island, some of them went to New Mapoon near Bamaga on the tip of Cape York, some of them went to Aurukun, and some of them went to Weipa. So again the removal of people was compounded.

I have spoken on a number of occasions to some of the ancestors of the Mapoon people. In Cairns, for instance, a large group of them are trying to understand how they can reclaim their community. It is not a pastoral lease but the community has mining interests all around it. The people in the community want to re-establish their own community, yet they have this problem. If the registration test as proposed is applied, we will have to say to a whole group of people from Mapoon, `Sorry, you don't qualify.'

The next example comes from Rosalind Kidd's book, The Way We Civilise It, from which I quoted a few days ago. In the community of Yarrabah near Cairns, almost all the people have come from somewhere else. What community do they belong to? That is the question that they ask. Many of them do not know where they came from, but Yarrabah has become their community. What kind of connection is required of them? Then there is the example from the time of the Second World War. Pastor Schwartz was the missionary at Cape Bedford in Cape York. Because he was a German he was regarded as a Nazi sympathiser. The belief was that he had perhaps infected the community at Cape Bedford, so the military authorities demanded that the mission be disbanded. Reverend Schwartz was kept under armed guard and his belongings were searched. The mission car was confiscated in 1942, leaving no transport for medical emergencies, et cetera. The 271 residents of Cape Bedford were transported about 2,000 kilometres to the Aboriginal community at Woorabinda in central Queensland.

The relocation was appallingly bungled. Under military and police guard, people were refused time to gather clothing and belongings. Apart from a meal at Cooktown, no food was available next morning, nor on the 14-hour boat trip to Cairns, nor on the overnight train until 5.30 a.m. the next day at Cardwell. Nothing was provided from that evening until Rockhampton was reached the following afternoon. Woorabinda was nowhere near ready to accept them and to cut a long story short—and if I had time, I would certainly recall all of the disaster of this removal—

talk.start.para: —Please don't!
—I think I should for your sake, Senator Boswell. I might say that this happened under a Labor government.

speech.para: Many of those people died. What kind of physical connection test are you going to apply to them? To what community do they belong, Cape Bedford in Far North Queensland or Woorabinda in Central Queensland? This is the problem that we have with the definition of the registration test that the government, and certainly Senator Harradine in his amendment, are putting upon us. I know there is considerable support for the refining of the registration test. I think everyone agrees with that. But it cannot be so refined that it creates a situation where the registration test is so onerous that it effectively wipes out accessibility to native title procedures.

It really is an issue of access to justice. A harsh test is not the issue. The injustice flows from a harsh test in combination with unreasonably tight time frames from notices that will have the effect of impairing or extinguishing native title. We believe the government is attempting to say to native title applicants, `Sure you can have native title. You even have native title procedures. Just use them but don't expect us to make them work.'

On the other hand, the Democrat-Greens (WA) amendments will ensure that there are no technical knockouts of native title. Professor Langton, whom I mentioned in my earlier speech, in response to a question from Senator Ferris on overlapping claims—the main excuse the government is using to substantiate such a massive high jump bar for indigenous people to access their rights—said:

So, in answer to Senator Ferris's question, I wanted to explain the problem in this way. I spoke before about how one of the principles which anthropologists have identified in order to ascertain the workings of an Aboriginal land tenure system is the notion of descent from an apical ancestor.

As with all human cultures, the ancestor may be real or legendary, to use a lay term. For instance, British royalty had at one time its constitution in divinity and it was believed that the king, or the queen, was the divine representative on earth.
It was called `the divine right of kings'. She continued:
That is why the monarch is the representative of the Church of England, because of the doctrine of the monarch as divinity.

In a similar way, most human cultures have a belief system about ancestry. These days with DNA and RNA testing, some of this can be affirmed or denied, but much of it still is not amenable to scientific inquiry. Belief systems are belief systems and as we know with racism, generally false propositions which operate on illogic are not amendable to facts. So in the same way belief systems are simply belief systems and there is no point in taking blood tests and doing DNA tests because it is not relevant to the exercise. One would not do a DNA test on the queen to see if she were, in fact, a descendant of God.
That is rather a strange notion. Professor Langton went on to say a number of other things. That is available to us all in the transcript of that hearing.

When we take into consideration the genocide that has happened to indigenous people, the provision of a physical connection test is an amendment that could easily have been drafted by the discredited historian David Irving. I appeal to the government and to the Senate to accept the Greens and Democrat amendments as fulfilling the need for a registration test which will sort out the various problems that have been enunciated.

We cannot accept Senator Harradine's amendment because it is based, we believe, on a false premise. We do recognise that Senator Harradine's amendment does improve the government's registration test, but neither the government's test nor the improvement which Senator Harradine is moving fulfils the basic principle that I have enunciated: the principle that, in the end, there are spiritual and cultural connections to land which are far deeper than any physical connection and that sometimes those kinds of connections can last for 200, 500 or 1,000 years, as in the case of the Jewish people—an example I gave in my previous speech. I commend our amendments to the committee.

talk.start.para: —Madam Chair, I am at a bit of a loss to know where we are. I thought we were dealing with government amendment 66.
—We are dealing with government amendments 66 to 69.

—Since everybody has been speaking generally, let me speak fairly briefly at this stage. I reject completely the statements that have been made about my amendment and I will come to that when I move the amendment. My amendment is to ensure that indigenous groups or members of indigenous groups who have been locked out by pastoralists or by actions of government, or those members of indigenous groups who have been stolen—the stolen generation—will be specifically included in the registration test, even if there is not one of their group currently alive who at some stage, even as a baby, has set foot on the land.

speech.para: I said in the beginning of this debate that I am not prepared to see a diminution of the common law rights of indigenous Australians to their land. I stand by that. The fact that is being forgotten here is that for those indigen ous groups to be entitled to native title they must have connection and descent, and the land must not have been subject to extinguishment. That is the CDE test. I think people have forgotten that. We are talking about native title; we are talking about the decisions in Mabo; we are talking about decisions in Wik. If you look at those, you do need CDE. You need contact, connection and descent because, in Mabo, the basis for native title was the rejection of the legal fiction, terra nullius. That is what we are dealing with here.
In order to ensure that we are giving an avenue to the genuine native title owners of the land we must establish some sort of registration test.

talk.start.para: —There is one. There is one built in.

—Senator Margetts says, `There is one.' After Waanyi, there is one? Have a word with persons within the indigenous communities and see how they feel about it. They feel that there should be a test which allows genuine native title holders to get into the first track.
—As opposed to only those with spiritual connections.

—Wait a minute. I will come to the spiritual connection in a minute. Have a word to others who are interested, including miners, pastoralists, governments and country townspeople—or city townspeople, for that matter. Those who want to see the High Court decisions upheld want to see a situation where all bogus claims are prevented from being successful and the huge number of overlapping claims which beset those who are concerned about this matter not able to get through the threshold test. What is wrong with that? What is wrong with having a proper test?

speech.para: We are looking at a question now of what the High Court said. We do need to recognise that the High Court made it clear which indigenous people are entitled to a recognition of their native title. The High Court recognised that native title existed, and it recognised that native title should be recognised by the community where there is connection and descent to the people who owned that land in 1788 when the first Europeans came to this land.

I now go to the arguments on the bill itself. In section 190B(5) the bill requires the registrar to be `satisfied that the factual basis described in the application . . . is sufficient to support the assertion that the native title rights and interests claimed exist.' Government amendment 73 expands that provision to spell out clearly that the factual basis on which it is asserted that native title rights and interests exist derives from the Mabo decision.

In section 190B(6) the bill requires the registrar to consider `that, prima facie, each of the native title rights and interests claimed in the application can be established.' There have been negotiations about this and I have made it perfectly clear to the government that I am concerned that that is too restrictive. Government amendment 73 changes this to `some rights and interests'. Previously, as the government wanted it, it said `. . . each of the native title rights and interests claimed in the application can be established'. The government has said `Okay, we will change this to `some rights and interests'.

Another amendment set up a register of those interests, including the spiritual interests and cultural interests of the indigenous group, which is very important to their connection to the land. I believe that this is a very significant amendment as it enables the native title claimant to be registered even if they are unable within the very strict time limits that are in the legislation to establish all of the claimed native title rights and interests.

To further improve this situation, opposition N34—perhaps, Senator Bolkus, that could be moved separately when the time comes—allows the register to be amended after registration so that native title claimants, when they come to negotiate, are able to negotiate about all the native title rights and interests which are then registered. That not only gives certainty to the pastoralists, the governments and those who need to consider the matters but also it gives a degree of certainty to the native title claimants. That is good.

The bill, in section 190B(7), introduces the traditional physical connection test which is not, strictly speaking, part of the common law test for the existence of native title. Unfortunately, many people seem to have been convinced that a requirement for a physical connection test is necessary to bring order into native title law. The amendments to the threshold test package which I have spoken about above will do far more to eradicate the spurious and scandalous claims than a physical connection test. When I said, `spoken about above', I meant the matters that I raised in this chamber in December. Honourable senators, if they are interested, can either go back to those or read the document entitled `Native Title Amendment Bill 1997: the Senate's amendments to the threshold test'. That is an eight-page document that was provided to me by my legal advisers.

If the government is insistent on this test, it needs to be ameliorated to ensure that those indigenous people who have been the victims of the locked gate and stolen generation problems are not prevented from having their claims registered when they have not given up their native title rights and interests to the lands of their ancestors. It is important for us to receive examples of this. As yet, I have not received examples of that situation. It is important to have some examples presented to us so that support can be maintained.

The government has gone some way to providing this situation in government amendment 73(7)(b). This does not go far enough given the fact that many of the victims of those policies and incidents, due to the scandalously low life expectancy among the indigenous, may no longer be living. Hence I propose to move N4 to add an extra generation to the government's physical connection test.

I come to Senator Woodley. Of all those people about whom he speaks, is there not any one of that indigenous group who is alive who, maybe as a child, was on that area? We are getting down to the practicalities now. I believe it is important when we deal with legislation to have a good understanding of what is being proposed and examples of how the amendments that are being put forward are going to somehow affect the rights of particular individuals.

The bill, in section 190B(8), does not add anything to the threshold test package. An application must not be made unless there is compliance with the matters set out in section 61A. However, this provision puts an obligation on to the registrar to ensure that the application does comply with section 61A prior to its being registered.

The bill, in section 190B(9), required the registrar not to register a claim where the native title rights and interests consisted of or included ownership of minerals (Extension of time granted) where the Crown owned the minerals. Since it is possible that native title rights may include ownership of minerals in circumstances where the Crown at common law has ownership, that provision went too far. The government's amendment No. 73 inserts the word `wholly' to take care of the situation where the Crown's radical title to minerals may be burdened by native title.

talk.start.para: —Earlier I spoke in general about the issues involved here. I suppose, like Senator Harradine, I thought we were going through the amendments sequentially. I have already indicated what the opposition will be doing regarding amendments 66 to 69. I want to spend a few minutes considering the core issue of this part of the debate, and that is the threshold test—the registration test—and how it should operate.

speech.para: The core issue is this: who is a genuine native title holder? How can that be resolved through the process? As Senator Harradine has said, a number of us in this place, in the community and among the working group are concerned that we are able to distinguish the bogus, fraudulent and overlapping claims from the genuine ones but, in doing so, we must ensure that there is still a course open for those with genuine claims to be able to pursue them.

In essence, the parliament needs to see how the High Court test in Mabo No. 2 can be best applied. When one listens to the debate, it is quite apparent that there are different views—those of the government; the opposition, which has a view shared with the Greens and the Democrats; and Senator Harradine. In a numbers sense, we are skating on thin ice and hopefully something will come up, through the evolving debate, and the votes.

We think that the government's position goes too far. It is too restrictive and it is a curtailment of the High Court test. We are concerned that we not go too far in taking away common law rights and we are concerned that the government's proposal does in fact that. At the same time, we are concerned that it does not allow a course for some genuine claims to be pursued. Our amendments provide not just for the single test in the government's bill—the physical connection test, which is reflected in the government's amendment 73(7)—but ensure also that three tests apply in the alternative. The amendment that we are pursuing today is identical to the amendment that we pursued in the debate last November and December.

We accepted then the test put up by the government at the time of traditional physical association—that is, that one member of the native title claim group has or previously had a traditional physical connection with the area. That is still the first leg of our three-part test. In the alternative, we felt it imperative that the parliament take into account the injustice related to those who had been locked out and were denied traditional physical association. It would have been quite unreasonable for the parliament not to have recognised the importance of factoring in the position of those who were dispossessed of their land by lock-outs or by other actions forced upon them. That constitutes the second part of our test.

The third part of our test is, in essence, to pick up the words of Mr Justice Brennan in Mabo. For us, it is important that, if the parliament is to be seen to be reflecting the full impact of the common law, then the words of Justice Brennan should be reflected in legislation. I remind senators that he said:

Where a clan or group has continued to acknowledge the laws and (so far as practicable) to observe the customs based on the traditions of the clan or group, whereby their traditional connexion with the land has been substantially maintained, the traditional community title of that clan or group can be said to remain in existence.
In other words, there should be an avenue for them also to pursue native title claims.

We are concerned that these two aspects of connection—the physical and, as a subset of physical, the denied physical, together with traditional association with the land—are still maintained in a threshold test which, at the same time, ensures that the bogus, fraudulent and overlapping claims can be dealt with. They are dealt with comprehensively in other aspects of the legislation already passed through the parliament and still to be considered here. One way or another, we are still concerned that this avenue be made available.

Let us keep in mind also that we are not dealing with these three alternatives in isolation. We are dealing with them given that the legislation, as passed last year and as to be passed this year, ensures that the evidentiary burden is much higher than it was in the pre-existing legislation. There has to be establishment of a prima facie case. A whole raft of requirements were adopted by the Senate last year that ensure that, not just in terms of overlaps but also in terms of the burden of proof. At a very preliminary stage the burden is such that much of the flotsam and jetsam, I suppose it could be called, is not allowed to go to base one.

Our position is to reflect that. Our position is to acknowledge that this test will work within a framework as has already been deliberated by the parliament. Our other objective is to ensure that we meet the requirements of common law. You are talking about potentially taking away the common law rights of people. No matter what anyone says or what interpretation one gives to the case in the High Court last week, it is fair to say that anyone who reads that case will come away with not just a feeling but an understanding that to take away one's common law rights would meet with a different response—a stronger response—from the High Court.

We have to ensure that we do not do that. Senator Harradine says, `Well, give us an example where, by deleting the Mabo-Brennan test, you are denying people access to justice and access to their rights.' There are instances involving people on Palm Island in the Forties where, with careful consideration, it may very well be that those people would be denied access under either the Harradine or the government test. We say that, if the view is that no-one will qualify under this particular test, there is no cost to anyone if we play it safe and ensure that this avenue is available to people.

There is some concern that the physical connection, as proposed by either Senator Harradine or Senator Minchin, is too restrictive. As I said, people in and around Palm Island in The Forties, for instance, may be denied access to native title claims because of the operation of the alternative test proposed. We will be pursuing our amendment that adopted last year. We see Senator Harradine's as a second best. We see the government's proposal as excessively restrictive and we will not be able to support that.

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Bolkus for that clear exposition on why Senator Harradine's proposal is going to fall short of the mark. Senator Harradine's amendment cuts out a whole category that was available last year and that was argued by the committee, including Senator Harradine, on very cogent grounds. That category defends the rights of indigenous people to make a claim through traditional connection with the land, even if they have been locked out or fail to have a direct connection in the interim.

speech.para: Senator Harradine said that my amendment was to ensure persons who have been locked out will be specifically included, but he meant some persons who have been locked out will be specifically included. What his amendment does is water down, withdraw from and reduce even the tests that were voted on by the Senate in December last year. In particular, it is taking away from many people their spiritual and traditional connection, which is the foundation of their connection with the land. It is taking that away as a tenable and acceptable claim when people want to reconnect themselves with the land.

Let us remember this: on all of these occasions, these people have not wanted to be disconnected. Their history is not one of wanting to leave. There is a terrible history involved here, and time and time again it has been visited on indigenous people and time and time again, through fraudulence, force or trickery, they have been removed from their land. Senator Woodley gave a gruesome account of how recently that has occurred on a large scale in Queensland, and we have to remember that.

I do not hear Senator Harradine getting up and being concerned about spurious and scandalous claims from people other than the indigenous people involved in this situation. The pall of potential misuse of this legislation hangs across the indigenous people. Why should that be the case? Why is it that Senator Harradine is moving back from the position that was held just last year, that he defended just last year?

I have two questions that I wish to have answered at the end of my comments. My first question is to Senator Minchin, who indicated on the weekend that a connection with the land is enough to give people the right to make a claim. I ask this: is any connection enough? Is a visit to the land enough? Can the government tell the committee if a visit to the land at some time in the past is enough to allow a traditional owner to make a claim?

My second question is to Senator Harradine. After Diaspora, did the Israelites have no right to go back to Israel? Did the generations of disconnection disclaim them? Are you opposed to the process of this century which saw the Jewish people going back to Israel, the return of the Israelites? That is what you are proposing here, Senator Harradine.

talk.start.para: —Was there no Israelite who had a physical connection test alive at that stage?
—Let us presume there was not. There are two standards here.
—Bullshit!
—Senator Harradine might say `bullshit', but I am saying that there are two standards here and he has just been discovered exhibiting them.
—Madam Chairman, I raise a point of order. I ask that the senators withdraw that offensive word.
—I withdraw.

—I will withdraw the repetition of the comment, but it points out that Senator Harradine has discovered here—and it is something I maintain—that, if a spiritual connection, a historic connection, a longing which is clear and patent, is good enough for people at the core of Christian tradition, it is good enough for people at the core of Aboriginal spiritual tradition. To not see that parallel and to back one but not the other is to discriminate, and that is again what is happening here.

speech.para: I was at Doomadgee in the gulf country last year and I met up again with one of the wonderful members of the Gunggalida community, Wadgular Binna.
