As we were standing in the bush there, a group of us put to her that at that stage it looked like spiritual connection may be discounted, even as far as negotiations on mining were concerned. Her response was instant: `Take away our spirituality and you take away our hearts. That is taking the hearts out of us as people.' We should remember that. There are too many broken hearts in the last two and a bit centuries of the history of the indigenous people in this country. We have to do the best we can, because not one indigenous person is here to be able to speak up for that feeling they have for the land. We have to try to put ourselves in their position and, if we do, we will be found wanting.

There are double standards being employed here and it is not a very nice process. Senator Margetts began with very, very strong words about cultural genocide this afternoon, but she is right. She is right that this is another process of dispossession, of killing culture, of killing connections, of killing hopes. I cannot understand it, and I have heard no argument here as to why we should retreat from the minimal position that the Senate accepted in December.

talk.start.para: —May I respond, and I do apologise to the committee for the remark that I made. I do feel that Senator Brown has misunderstood totally what native title is all about.
—A mutual misunderstanding, it seems.

—Let us test that. This bill is not about granting native title. This parliament is not about granting native title. To do that, we are virtually saying that we in this parliament have to act paternalistically to indigenous people in Australia who have native title. Even the High Court did not grant them native title. It recognised that they had native title.
—But you're taking it away.

—In this particular regard, some people are talking about a traditional physical connection to land. That traditional physical connection may have commenced at the beginning of this century, and you are saying that you will put an `or' there so that those people are entitled to a native title to that land. You are not going to get such a claim recognised because it has to fit within Mabo. That is the whole point about it.

speech.para: Mabo is essential to the success of a native title claim, absolutely essential. To say that Mabo or a physical connection means you could get registration, even if you cannot satisfy Mabo, is a nonsense. Of course you cannot. You have to prove CDE—connection, descent and that extinguishment has not taken place on the land. Let us get that clear in our heads. That is what it is all about. If you are operating on a basis of misunderstanding there, as I suspect that you are—

talk.start.para: —Well, you're wrong.

—Have a look at what you have been saying over this period—and I will be happy to have a look at the Hansard . You are really not understanding that Mabo is essential to the success of a native title claim.

speech.para: Let us be perfectly clear: my amendment will ensure that those dispossessed in the last two generations will be able to be registered. That is what my amendment does. You, Senator Brown, through you, Madam Chairman, are going to vote against that. When the time comes—and we will deal with it then—you are going to vote against that.

talk.start.para: —You're going to vote against yourself.

—I am moving the amendment. I am not likely to be voting against it. I refer to a point that Senator Woodley made, and I just ask him about the areas and the peoples he was concerned about. The committee has to ask itself: is there no-one alive today who lived on that land? That is what you have to ask yourself. Is there no-one alive today who actually lived on that land, even if they were an infant and are now living a thousand miles away?

speech.para: It might be desirable for the committee, rather than toing and froing, to get to a situation where we can have an amendment before us that we are voting on. As I understand it, the amendment that is before us is government amendment No. 66, is it not?

talk.start.para: —It is 66 to 69.
—Can we get rid of that, and then I am happy to debate the issues when they come forward?

—I hear Senator Harradine's appeal. I have been seeking to debate all of the amendments, or at least those that hang together, because then, when we come to them, we can move through the voting fairly succinctly. If that is not so, I am happy to be guided by other people.

speech.para: Senator Harradine did ask me a question about whether there were any people alive. Of course there are, otherwise they could not make a claim. The problem is, however, Senator Harradine, as I was saying, in making the physical connection the fundamental test, even going back a generation, you still do not solve the problem for those people I was speaking about. Take the Mapoon case: you have different groups of people, all of whom have a physical connection, making different claims, and some claims were not being allowed because even the degrees of physical connection were being debated. That was the problem.

Let me see if I can help us with a way through. The Democrats agree there must be a registration test but the real problem is the resourcing of representative bodies. That is where the problem has come about in trying to apply the registration test where we have had overlapping claims and, in Senator Harradine's words, some bogus claims as well. Where even the 1993 act itself has been used and the representative bodies have been able to operate properly, they have been able to resolve those overlapping claims.

Take the example which is quoted regularly of the whole Kalgoorlie area and the goldfields. Just last week the Goldfields Land Council pointed out to me that by using the 1993 act they had been able, through negotiation, to collapse the 57 overlapping claims into two and in fact are now, through discussions with the mining companies in that area, on the point of signing agreements very beneficial to all the parties involved. So if the representative bodies are properly resourced, then even by using the 1993 act they are able to resolve the whole problem of overlapping claims. But the resourcing is critical.

Even in the 1993 act, bogus claims are knocked out. `Vexatious and frivolous claims'—I think is the wording—are not allowed. There have been vexatious and frivolous claims made—I have no doubt about that—but they are being dealt with, and they can be dealt with under the 1993 act, let alone under any amendments that we might propose.

Senator Harradine is right—many of these claims will not succeed simply because the native title has already been extinguished. I would point out that Mabo actually also said that the doctrine of terra nullius was null and void. By abolishing that doctrine, in one sense the whole of the continent should be open to claim. But, of course, as we know, the 1993 act made it quite clear that many parts of the continent are not subject to claim and native title has been extinguished in many parts of it.

I do not know whether I want to open up the debate about the Jewish people, but the point I was trying to make was that, again, a physical connection is not required of people who want to return to the state of Israel. The ancestors of some of those people have been separated for 200, 500, a thousand, two thousand years. In fact, you would have to go into myth and legend if you tried to trace any connection between the current state of Israel and the original tribes of Israel. Nevertheless, Jewish people have a very strong connection. It is not physical connection; it is cultural connection. It is a connection of spirit; a connection of race, if you like.

The same problem, however, exists in many other parts of the world. The dispossession of the Scots, the Irish or the Welsh from their lands has never been properly settled. Those issues remain today. It is only as we negotiate with people properly and sit down with them that we begin to solve those problems. I am glad to see that, at least in relation to Scotland and Wales, there are now ways through after 700 years in some cases. Unfortunately, the Irish problem remains with us.

What we are saying is there are historical examples which give us pause. There is no direct connection between them. But what they say to us is, in terms of history, we need to learn the lessons that you need to deal with people with respect and deal with them properly. We need to negotiate outcomes which people can own and live with. Otherwise, the sore will continue to fester until finally it has to be dealt with. That is my contribution.

talk.start.para: —Senator Harradine mentioned in this debate this afternoon that someone would have had to—and I took it down—`set foot as a baby on the land.' Schedule 2, part 1, on page 206 of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2], relates to physical connection. Proposed subsection (7) states:

speech.para: The Registrar must be satisfied that at least one member of the native title claim group currently has or previously had a traditional physical connection with the area covered by application.

So we are not talking about `set foot as a baby'; we are talking about lived in what is considered to be a traditional physical connection with the area. I am wondering where this might lead to in the end. This might lead to the actual footprints—the tracks where people stood. Maybe we will get so tight in revisiting this over time that only those places which were regularly trod will become the areas where registration is accepted. I believe that it is a problem.

Over time concern has been expressed to me by a number of people, including the very people with whom Senator Harradine danced the other day. Gladys said to me, `I hope Senator Harradine understands this is a dance about our land and our culture.' I am not sure he did. The information I have received from the Mirimbiak nation's aboriginal corporation talks about the cases in Victoria, Victoria having a history of close occupation. I will read some parts from this letter:

Further, it may affect the way national laws regarding Indigenous people are implemented in Victoria. It may affect the way the registration test is implemented. Therefore the test itself should be carefully drafted to prevent perpetuating this stereotype.

This requirement emphasises the government's conception of native title as something that purely exists in the physical domain. It emphasises the need as expressed by the State Government for native title holders to prove physical connection and presence on land, before any claims to spiritual connection will even be considered. Victorian Aboriginal people are not seen as having been on the land—"they have all been assimilated".
It goes on, and this, I believe, is a statement from the court:
It may amount to a pre-judgement about the nature of native title in Victoria.

It is inappropriate, before trial, for the nature of native title in Victoria to be pre-judged by the imposition of a threshold test, which may impose the wider community's pre-conceptions of what is Aboriginality. This will have particular pernicious effects in Victoria.
It is not the only way to achieve that end.

The most appropriate means of addressing the "problem" of over-lapping and ambit claims is by means of a well resourced, strong, and accountable—both legally and culturally—representative body. Mirimbiak is part of the way to achieving these aims with Victoria's native title holders. To date, there are no overlapping claims in Victoria.

I just wondered if Senator Harradine did a statistical analysis. I do not think this is about numbers, but it seems to be the way Senator Harradine is presenting it. If you did a statistical analysis of those potential claims which may now or retrospectively be either questioned or declared invalid, are these the claims that are likely to be associated with overlapping claims? I have never argued that overlapping claims are a problem per se.

talk.start.para: —Why?

—I have mentioned this on several occasions. The problem that existed in 1993 was the fact that the bill was drafted for white land law. It was therefore impossible to assume that Aboriginal land law would fit neatly and conveniently within European or white land law. It is our expectations of land connection and land ownership about Aboriginal people which, on a number of occasions, have created the problem. There are overlapping land associations depending on the situation, depending on the season, depending on the clan group. That is Aboriginal culture. There are times when people speak for themselves. There are times when people speak for wider groups. There are times when they cannot speak for their land connections without particular circumstances being involved. There are circumstances where different groups can speak for the same area of land. They are legitimate multiple claims.

speech.para: Aboriginal people are being required to deal sometimes with hundreds of mining claims on the land for which they speak. We do not seem to think that that is a problem. We do not extinguish mining claims for that reason. I believe the problem is, in many cases, firstly, the way some cowboy corporations are acting and misusing the act and, secondly, the resourcing that is available not just to land councils but to other representative bodies—they could be corporations or other Aboriginal bodies—who are trying to deal with the issues and represent the people for whom they are set up.

This is important. When I spoke last on this issue, I talked about the situation in Western Australia. I talked about a situation where the health of a particular person or the failing health of a particular person may, if this bill goes through in this form, be the defining condition of whether or not a claim is recognised. I have a statement I would like to read from the Swan Valley Nyungah Community, a statement concerning their spiritual connection to the land and the 10-point plan. They say:

para.inline: The Spiritual Beliefs cannot be separated from the Aboriginal People or the Land.

speech.para: The Spiritual Connection to the Land is a given thing to us by Birthright and cannot be changed.

The Spiritual Beliefs are our Title Deeds to our Land, and we the people give no given consent to no Aboriginal groups or Labor or Liberal or any politician to say that they can do this to us—to try and separate our Spiritual Beliefs from us and the Land and our Land Title Claims.
It is not a question of one generation here and now. It is begun from the Beginning of Time with our very existence through all generations from then to now and it doesn't change.
The Spiritual Beliefs, the Spiritual Dreaming cannot be taken out of the Land just because people wish to do so now.
They have no authority, they have no given consent from the Aboriginal Nation as a whole.
Land Title Claims comes from within the Land and that is where our Life begun.

para.inline: Our Spiritual Beliefs are the Roots of our Land Title Claims and our Beginning and they are not allowed to be ignored or not considered. No-one has any authorisation to alter or take our Spiritual Connection out of the Native Title Act.

speech.para: OUR SPIRITUAL BELIEFS, OUR SPIRITUAL DREAMINGS ARE THE ROOTS OF OUR LAND TITLE CLAIMs.
It is important to realise that that, for many people, is the most important basis. What we would be saying in relation to a registration test is that you do not get over the first hurdle

unless we ignore the overall importance of your spiritual connection. What we are saying if we vote for the government's position or Senator Harradine's amendment is that the pivotal point will be your level or your group's level of physical connection because you will not get any further unless that has been proven. I believe this is basically a disrespect of the importance of the spiritual connection to land. Simply dealing with figures, simply dealing with what is considered to be legal outcomes and simply putting in some kind of statistical argument will never overcome that huge gulf that seems to be existing between the government and what many people are telling us on this issue.

I said to Senator Harradine—and he interjected at the time—that there is a registration test. If the portions of the bill which deal with the physical connection test are knocked out, there will still be a registration test. It may not be an ideal one, but there will still be a registration test. There are many hurdles for people to meet when making native title claims and the government has made sure there are as many as possible. However, it is simply not conscionable to suggest that to register and to gain the right to negotiate Aboriginal people have to pass a physical connection test for all and more of the reasons we are giving.

When we do get to that portion, I will not be moving all the Greens (WA)-Democrat amendments because we would like to concentrate on those areas which are most salient to the debate today. The first area where I will be moving an amendment is when we get to schedule 2, item 63. I would like to ask people to consider in the meantime dealing with Senator Harradine's amendment first, if possible, so we get a clear picture of where the Senate is going on that, because it is quite clear statements have been made by Senator Woodley now and by the Greens in relation to our voting pattern on those issues.

talk.start.para: —Again I think there has been a misunderstanding of what we are all about. We are not saying what native title claimants should receive other than a statutory provision which gives them access. We are actually talking about statutory procedures which, if there is a registration of a claimant group, will enable that claimant group to have access to the land and to a right to negotiate over the registered interests, including spiritual or otherwise. The government is saying—it is rather insistent upon this—that those statutory procedures should be based on certain facts. In negotiation with the government, it has now placed before the Senate some amendments which will, to a certain extent, ameliorate the situation within the bill. So we are not determining what indigenous group could achieve native title.

speech.para: I have asked continuously in discussions here and around the place for an example. Senator Margetts said that the people with whom I danced would be disadvantaged. Of course, they would not be disadvantaged.

talk.start.para: —No, Brian, that's not what I said; I said they were hoping you would understand the importance of their spirituality. Well, obviously, you haven't.
—I do understand.
—I didn't quote them as an example of not having physical connection, at all.
—I apologise. May I say to you that I do have a great deal of regard for their spiritual and cultural connection to the land and so did the High Court.

speech.para: What is more, no credit was given to me for negotiating the registration of interests which makes it certain that those persons can have the right to negotiate in respect of those areas of land which are important to their spirituality and to their customs. Nobody has said, `There's a tick for Harradine.' The government has acknowledged that and placed it now before you as an amendment. It is a significant improvement, might I say, and there will be a number of others as a result of hours upon hours of discussions and examination of the matter. I have also asked, `Give us an example of a group of indigenous people who—

talk.start.para: —Victoria—I gave it to you; Mirimbiak.

—No, just a minute. I asked for an example of a group of indigenous people who will not be able to pursue a native title claim. The group which Senator Woodley spoke about would be able to meet the test that the government has applied. But let us take as an example a group who are relying only on a traditional cultural connection with certain land upon which there is some other group established at the present moment and say that they can—and I have not been given any example of that, but let us say that they can. There is nothing to prevent those people from applying to the court and proving their native title claims. There is nothing in this legislation that will prevent them from doing that.
—Except maybe a lot of money, Brian.

—I am trying to deal with the situation which we face by the Mabo and the Wik decisions and which we face by the government legislation. I am trying to see that justice is done in the establishment of statutory procedures which will give a degree of certainty to the native title claimants and to other stakeholders. I think that is what we should be aiming at. I say again that, when the time comes, you will have to presumably justify why you are not voting for an amendment which covers the stolen generation or the locked gates situation. Again, I have not been given any examples of those people who would not now come within the test being considered by the Senate, but if there are—and I am assuming there may well be—I am proposing this as at this particular stage.

—The real issue here is obviously between us on the non-government side. It is interesting to see that Senator Minchin has not really had to participate too much in the debate for the last few hours. The choice really comes down to Senator Harradine's amendment or Labor's amendment as to whether we apply a threshold test which reflects the common law.

speech.para: I think if we are to have a clear understanding of where we are going here, it would be very fair to say that there is a mile of difference between both the Harradine and the Labor amendments and the government's. I think we need to place on the record that there is an enormous chasm between the alternative proposed by the government and the alternative proposed by the opposition parties. We will move ours and will stick with ours because we believe that it more fully reflects the letter of the common law. But I for one have been trying to meet Senator Harradine's challenge in terms of trying to name one group of people who would be denied access under his test as opposed to the one proposed by Labor. It is important for us, and I still maintain that it is important for the parliament, to be seen to be implementing rather than curtailing the common law in particular in this area.

When it comes to the vote here, we all should recognise that there could be an enormous injustice if both the non-govern ment tests go down, not just an enormous injustice but enormous injustices. For instance, earlier on I said that in the Palm Island case, people moved from western Queensland. The Wangkangurru people from the south-east corner of the Simpson Desert were moved in the 1940s. They know the sites; they are a very traditional people and they are imbued with a traditional connection with their country. They associated, and continue to associate, themselves with it, but their parents have died.

In those circumstances where parents have died, they would not meet the government test. They would meet the opposition test, but they would also meet the Harradine test. It is important for us to recognise that, if neither of these two tests gets through the Senate, an injustice will be perpetrated on these people. So I say there is probably a marginal difference between the Harradine and the opposition tests in all practicality. We believe our test is a—

talk.start.para: —Oh!

—Senator Margetts, go through them all. I will go through a few more in a minute. The fact is that there is some difference between us and Senator Harradine, but there is a mile of difference between Senator Harradine and the government, especially if you are from the south-east corner of the Simpson Desert still trying to maintain a claim. Their land is now under an Aboriginal Land Act Queensland claim. As I have said, they would be protected under either the opposition or the Harradine proposal. They are one group.

speech.para: People on Great Keppel Island are in the same situation; they were moved not in the 1940s but in the 1920s. So if they had one person from that claim group who could meet the Harradine test, they would still be able to pursue their claim. It would not be pursuable under the government test. Fraser Island is another one. As to Fraser Island, it is a national park and, as a consequence, I do not know that they would have any claim right under the act. They would not. In respect of those people, they might have been moved in the 1890s, closer to the turn of the century, but their rights have already been dispensed with—I suppose that is the best way to say it—by legislation.

Let us not vote on this without appreciating that there is a big difference on the ground between the two alternative tests and the government test. The test that we are putting up reflects Brennan in Mabo, but Justice Brennan in Mabo also made reference, as did other justices, to the tide of history washing away the connection. That is something that we also need to take into account if we were, for instance, to take the view that, if the opposition test was not to succeed, nothing else is anywhere near as good as that; therefore, we will vote against all other provisions.

I suppose I am calling for both the Greens and the Democrats to keep in mind the enormous chasm between the Harradine test and the government test. We moved the Mabo-Brennan test last time. We still think it is a true reflection of the law and we think it is a better expression of the law, but if that test is not successful in the ensuing votes, then we will have to have a very close look at the Harradine test—in particular, to look at the injustices that would be perpetrated on claim groups if a more reasonable test than the government's is not successful.

talk.start.para: —It is extraordinary to make a call to the Greens and Democrats but not to Senator Harradine on this. It is extraordinary to in some way or other feel that the wider parameters that the amendment we are pursuing with Labor gives to ensure that Aboriginal people are not cut out in being able to register a claim is not a better position than the constricted one that Senator Harradine brings forward, but then to say that it is not Senator Harradine that the appeal should be made to. The Labor Party has brought forward the position that Senator Harradine took in December last year. Senator Harradine is sliding away from it and Senator Bolkus says, `Hey, Democrats and Greens, let's slide too because all will be lost otherwise.' How about Senator Bolkus appealing to Senator Harradine to hold his ground for once?
—I've done that for a while.

—How about doing it in the chamber if you have been doing it for a while? How about asking him to have some resolve as far as the rights of the indigenous people are concerned? Senator Bolkus said that in the case of Great Keppel Island, where the people were dispossessed in the 1920s or thereabouts, if one person has still got a connection through a parent who was brought from Great Keppel Island they will be right. The question immediately becomes: what happens if that one person dies?
—We had better hurry up and pass the bill.
—It is not a trite matter, it is a very important question.
—Of course it is important.
—It is not a case of hurrying up and passing the bill. It just shows you how brittle it is to draw a dividing line, as Senator Harradine is doing—and one that is so close.
—What is the difference?

—Exactly right, and that is why Senator Harradine's position is not the same as or close to what we have got. It is a very big concession to the government, against the interests of the indigenous people. Without knowing it, you have argued that very cogently. If one person dies out of a clan group it loses its right to register a claim, even though the clan group as a whole has a tradition and an attachment to their island, to their land. Why should we be cutting those people out through an amendment that Senator Harradine has brought forward to try to make the government see this as being more acceptable? Why shouldn't we leave it to the court? Why shouldn't we leave the registration available to people who have a legitimate claim? Why shouldn't they have their day in court? These are all legitimate questions.

speech.para: I again put to Senator Minchin, who is representing the government, the question I asked earlier—and I will keep going until I get an answer—

talk.start.para: —If you give him a chance to get up he might be able to answer a few questions.

—Senator Calvert, you have been noticeable by your failure to get up at any stage in this process today, so you should not be giving injunctions to me. The question to Senator Minchin is: on the weekend on Channel 7 were you saying that any visit to traditional land is going to be enough to be a connection which will give that claimant the right to proceed with registration? If you were not saying that, what is the level of visitation that is required to give a traditional connection with the land?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I would not mind saying a few things just to interrupt the conversation going on on the other side of the chamber which does not seem to involve the government much. I want to bring the debate back to what we are really talking about. It does seem to be premised on an assumption that this registration test is the gateway to the pursuit of a native title claim when, of course, it is not.

speech.para: The act sets out a procedure for the acceptance of applications for determinations of native title with the Federal Court. It is a very simple procedure. There is no physical connection test and claims can be accepted and pursued in order to get a determination and then have declared native title rights exercisable under an order of the Federal Court.

What we are talking about here is when, a claim having been accepted by the Federal Court—and therefore able to be pursued in the court—we move to the next stage, which is reference to the tribunal and the question of whether it is registered by the tribunal in order for the claimants to have access to considerable statutory rights—not common law rights but statutory rights; that is, the right to negotiate a set of procedural rights not generally available to any other titleholders in Australia, created by this parliament and, as I say, statutory in nature.

What we are proposing is a statutory test in order to determine which claimants who have had their claims accepted by the Federal Court for determination should then, in addition, have access to this very generous set of procedural rights called the statutory right to negotiate. It is appropriate that there be a rigorous test. Everybody seems to agree on that. The question is: how rigorous? What we have said is that, in relation to physical connection, the registrar needs to be satisfied that at least one member of the native title claim group currently has or previously had a traditional physical connection with any part of the land or waters covered by the application.

In answer to Senator Brown, it will be a matter for the registrar to determine whether he or she is satisfied that there is at least one person who currently has or previously had the traditional physical connection with any part of the land or waters covered by the application. That is entirely a matter for the registrar. As to the question of whether native title is determined or not, that is a matter for the courts. We leave it entirely to the courts to apply the Mabo test. The Mabo test was that they have maintained their traditional connection—and that means from the time of settlement—and that the native title has not in the meantime been extinguished by an act of government. That is entirely a matter for the courts to determine.

Of course, once a claimant has a determination—having passed the court test—and is a determined holder, then they automatically have the right to negotiate. They do not have to go through this process; this is a process for claimants. Once they are determined holders they automatically have the right to negotiate in respect of any future mining or compulsory acquisitions.

I am happy for you all to argue among yourselves about this, but you have to premise your argument on what this test is all about; it is about access to a statutorially created set of procedural rights that are not part of the common law. The High Court has said nothing about it, nor has it created the statutory right to negotiate. This is a creature of this parliament. It is appropriate that this parliament set a reasonable threshold for access to these procedural rights, remembering all the time that it is entirely a matter for the courts to determine what traditional connection actually means.

I think most Australians probably presume that what the High Court was talking about was some sort of physical connection. We are not saying that that is the case. It is left to the courts ultimately to determine, case by case, whether traditional connection is a requisite for a determination that people hold native title. That is a matter for the courts. All we are saying is that, if someone wants access to this set of procedural rights which is not generally available to anyone else—the person is only a claimant, remember; the person has not had a determination that they actually hold the native title—then one member of the group has to satisfy the registrar that they currently have or had a connection. The obverse is to say that someone, as a claimant group, can have access to this set of procedural rights even though not one member of the claim group has ever had any connection to any part of the land in question. That is what is being proposed. That is where we draw the line.

talk.start.para: —It has been said to me on many occasions by a number of indigenous representatives that one of the few `benefits' of the legislation so far is the right to negotiate. This is what we are talking about. It is not a small thing. It is not just something on the way. It is not whether or not someone has their name registered; it is whether or not someone is cut off from the right to negotiate. If people are denied the right to negotiate on land to which they have a spiritual belonging, it is a catastrophe. If people do not have the ability to negotiate on the land to which they belong in a truly spiritual way, if they do not have the right to negotiate because the government has a very narrow idea of what Aboriginal culture and spirituality in connection with the land is all about, that is a catastrophe. That is what we are arguing.

speech.para: I need to ask Senator Harradine or even perhaps Senator Bolkus a question. Given the complex nature of the culture of various Aboriginal nations around this continent, what happens when people cannot speak of their parents? What happens in those situations where the law of Aboriginal people requires that they cannot speak of their parents or other relatives once they have died? What may be necessary to establish physical connection in the test that Senator Harradine has suggested? What happens in a situation where a person's parent—mother or father—is not their birth mother or father through circumstance or through culture? How does the government expect a court to deal with such a situation when the court will, according to this bill, be instructed not to take these issues into consideration in any greater way than it would in the case of any other titleholder?

How do we deal with the intricacies of Aboriginal culture when Aboriginal families are not necessarily made up in the same way as we would define `family' in white Australian culture? How do we deal with the situation where people cannot speak of dead relatives? How will Senator Harradine's amendment in relation to physical connection one generation, two generations or seven generations later, deal with that?

talk.start.para: —I think it is fair for me to give an answer to Senator Harradine's question to me some time ago. I do not know if this does answer the question because I am again having difficulty fixing the parameters of this debate.

speech.para: An example, Senator Harradine, of a group which I do not think would pass your test is the Turrbal group. The Turrbal group of people inhabited Brisbane in the early days. We are now beginning to uncover some of their story, particularly because of Tom Petrie, one of the early settlers of Brisbane, who recorded a lot of the history of the Aboriginal people.

The Turrbal people were massacred in Brisbane in the 1850s and were thought to be extinct. But, because we have been able to uncover this history, it is known that Maroochy Barambah, who is recognised by all the Aboriginal people of south-east Queensland as being one of the Turrbal people, is a descendant—I only have her English name—of Kitty. Kitty is a Turrbal woman who escaped that massacre and fled to a part of south-east Queensland near the town of Kenilworth. She has made a claim. It is not a claim over people's backyards; it is simply a claim to enable the Turrbal people to have some participation in decision making in relation to some of the places of special significance in and around Brisbane. The Turrbal people would like to have a particular place set aside as a keeping place for their artefacts. I am not sure whether Maroochy Barambah would ever qualify in a physical connection test because of the break in the generations, although we are now beginning to find the links.

The other problem we have in Queensland is, sad to say, that many of the files in the department have disappeared. Whether that is deliberate or not, I do not know—I suspect it is. Some of the files which were previously used in research have themselves disappeared in recent days. This is one of the problems we face. I do not know whether that satisfies your question, Senator Harradine, but those are the problems we face.

talk.start.para: —The question is that amendments 66 to 69 be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye, those against no, the ayes have it. Senator Brown, you are too late.
—No, I am not too late.
—I had already put the question, as far as I was concerned.

—I am prepared to allow it to be put, but I have to note here that a vote is not taken until a declaration has been made. I was on my feet and I should be acknowledged. It is very important that members are acknowledged and are not cut out on any specific point. It is not for the chair to know what a member is going to put to the committee.
—Do you want to let it go or do you want to speak, Senator Brown?
—Let it go.
—The amendments are carried.

—I put it to you, Senator Minchin, that there is now some confusion as to what the government means by a traditional connection. You still have not clarified whether a visit to a traditional area by a member of a claimant group is sufficient to have established a physical connection. Can you outline to the committee what the government's intention is, as far as its legislation is concerned, in requiring visitations in establishing traditional connection?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I would have thought that Senator Brown would be pleased to know that the government is not seeking to circumscribe the registrar's proper discretion by setting any sort of arbitrary requirements of that kind. It is for the registrar, as an independent official of the Native Title Tribunal, to satisfy him- or herself strictly in accordance with the act as passed by this parliament; that is, the registrar must satisfy him- or herself that at least one member of a claim group currently has, or previously had, a traditional physical connection with any part of the land or waters covered by the application. That discretion is left to the registrar. The registrar is a statutory official and, based on the contents of the application and all the information supplied with the application, and on all the other matters that are required to be put before the registrar, the registrar must then meet his or her statutory obligations.

speech.para: We are not seeking to circumscribe it in any way, other than in what is in the proposed subsection 7 as to the requirement. I would have thought you would be satisfied and pleased that we are not seeking to circumscribe it or put any arbitrary conditions because it will depend, case to case, on the land being claimed and the nature of the native title rights being claimed, et cetera. So the discretion is left to the registrar.

talk.start.para: —On Channel 7 on the weekend the minister said that it is an unreasonable and unworkable position for a claim to be registered, even if not one member of the claim has ever had any physical connection to the land claim. Were you saying there that it is a reasonable and workable proposition for a claim to be registered if one member of a claim group has ever had any physical connection to the land claim?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The obverse of what I said is that, according to the government test, it is reasonable for a claim to be registered—subject to satisfying the other parts of the registration test, of course—where at least one member of a claim group can satisfy the registrar that they have now, or previously had, a traditional physical connection with any part of the land or waters covered by the application. From our point of view, we think it is an entirely reasonable proposition to put that that is a minimum requirement. As I say, the government regards this bill as a compromise.

speech.para: I had plenty of people saying, `The right to negotiate should not apply to anyone but determined holders, not to claimants.' No, we are allowing it to apply to claimants. Others said, `Everybody in the claim group should have a current physical connection.' No, we did not say that. Many have said, `Why are you acknowledging any past connection?' And so on. From the government's point of view, this is an entirely reasonable proposition. All we are saying is that to pass this part of the test, the registrar has to be satisfied that just one member, at some stage in their lives, had that traditional physical connection with any part of the land or waters claimed. This cannot possibly be described as an onerous test, given that we are not talking about whether or not their native title claim can be pursued in the Federal Court. Of course, it can.

It is up to the court to decide, in terms of having a determination of native title, what sort, if any, of traditional physical connection is required. That is a matter for the courts. All we are saying is that if you have not already had a determination—remembering that, if you have had a determination, this does not apply to you and you get the right to negotiate—your status is as a claimant and there is this quite minimal physical connection test to be satisfied.

talk.start.para: —I wonder whether I could get agreement from the committee, when we do reach schedule 2, item 63, that we put Senator Harradine's amendment first.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —Senator Harradine's amendment is premised on the government's amendments to the registration test. I do think, as we have discussed the amendments in general terms, that it makes sense for the government amendments to be put first so that we know what bill we are dealing with—that this is the government's bill—and then for other amendments to be dealt with sequentially. Senator Harradine's amendment is premised on the amendments put by the government, which, I think it has been said, are more acceptable to the Senate than was the original government position.
—Minister, you may care to move amendment 70.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I move:

Insert:
; (g) a description of the native title rights and interests in the claim that:
(i) the Registrar in applying subsection 190B(6); or

considered, prima facie, could be established.

talk.start.para: —I seek a point of clarification there. I thought we had put amendments 66 to 69. Was that finally voted on?
—Yes.
—It wasn't 66 to 76?
—No. We are now dealing with government amendment No. 70. You have a proposed amendment to that, Senator Harradine.

—I wish to respond to Senator Woodley's question about the Turrbal people. The question there is whether or not they can meet the Mabo test. On the facts that have been presented it is not at all clear to me as to whether, after the 1850 massacre, they have lost their traditional connection with the land.
—I don't know.

—No, but if they have lost the traditional connection with the land, they are not likely to be determined as native title holders under the Mabo test, because the Mabo test indicated that if they lost traditional connection—
—Physical—you're talking about the physical connection.
—No, Mabo was talking about a traditional connection to the land. If they have lost that—
—Senator Woodley was talking about the physical, not the spiritual—
—Order, Senator Margetts!
—I see. Well, if the person could meet the physical test, has she visited the land or whatever—
—You are missing the point, Brian—the spiritual connection.

—Through you, Mr Chairman, let us make it perfectly clear what Mabo decided, because this is essential for an understanding. If they have lost a traditional connection with the land, then under Mabo they would not be determined as native title holders.
—She may have a traditional connection—a traditional spiritual connection. We don't know.
—Order, Senator Margetts. It is not appropriate for you to intervene in the debate in that way.
—Through you, Mr Chairman, that includes spiritual connection, laws and customs and so forth. I am just trying to respond genuinely to a question that I was asked by Senator Woodley.

—Regarding opposition amendments RN34 and RN35, Senator Harradine requested that we deliberate on them separately, and I am quite happy to do that. In respect to both amendments, we are trying to accommodate a situation where you might have, for instance, multiple claims in a particular claim. As the provisions now stand, in those circumstances there is no capacity for an ongoing consideration of the claims separately. We are concerned to ensure that where a registrar makes a determination in respect of some of the claims the registrar does have sufficient flexibility to, for instance, defer consideration of some of the claims or all aspects of the overall application and deliberate on them at a later date. That is why we will move the amendment to reflect the words `continue to consider' in RN35 and `thereafter considers' in RN34.

speech.para: There has been what I would claim to be a typographical error in respect of RN34. The amendment says that we replace the words `consider, prima facie, can be established' with the words `or thereafter considers, prima facie, could be established'. I will move it in an amended form so that it can read `or thereafter considers, prima facie, could be established'. In that way we use the same word as in the government's legislation. Otherwise it might trigger a debate about different levels of evidentiary burdens and so on. So RN34 replaces the words `considers, prima facie, could be established' with the words `or thereafter considers, prima facie, could be established'.

I do not think there is a need to make any such change to RN35. We are trying to pick up on a situation where a registrar may determine that there is a need to come back to a particular application. The law does not adequately provide that. This flexibility is something that we think is important. We would hope that even the government would support it.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I regret to say that I do not think the government can support this because of what may well be the practical implications of it. It invites claimants to continue to seek forever and a day to have their registered claim amended in order to incorporate particular native title rights and interests they have claimed which have not been prima facie established in the first instance.

speech.para: I do not know how long that process would go on. Remember that you are dealing with hundreds of claims. If you have the registrar constantly in a process of having to revisit claims upon the presentation in unknown circumstances by the claimants to have additional rights and interests registered, then how does that affect any ongoing right to negotiate process? This is about which rights and interests can be dealt with in the right to negotiate process. What if you are halfway through a right to negotiate process and another set of rights and interests is added to the register? We think it is impractical. We think the test as proposed is the only way in which the registrar can sensibly deal with this in which parties to a right to negotiate can sensibly negotiate without this sort of open door to further rights and interests being claimed and possibly entered on the register.

talk.start.para: —Minister, the provisions in the legislation have certain time limits. You want certainty, and you want to try to have these claims in and have them within those fairly tight parameters: what if additional information arises later, and they come to light after the three months have expired, for example? What then? Are you saying that that is the finish—complete, no more? There might be very strong evidence which would have convinced the registrar to have the claimant group registered.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The time limits are known to us. You get three months now, I think it is, to lodge a claim, and another month for it to be considered. That is in response to a section 29 notice. Anyone can lodge a claim at any time. If we are not talking about the pressure of a section 29 notice, they have as much time as they like to make out their claim and to seek to have it registered.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 7.30 p.m.

talk.start.para: —I wish to raise one matter that carries over from the previous consideration. Does Senator Harradine want each of the amendments to be treated separately?
—I am voting in favour.

—Thank you, Senator. I did say that there was a need to move N34 in amended form to replace the word `can' with the word `could', and that also needs to happen with N35. At the end of the first line where it makes it clear that the registrar `can' that should read `could'. I seek leave to move to make those changes. Basically it is the same language as the government's in terms of whether it should be `can' or `could', but the principle is a little different.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: (N34) At the end of paragraph 186(1)(g), add "or thereafter considers, prima facie, could be established".
(N35) After paragraph 186(1)(g), insert:
Note: The Registrar may wish to enter some rights or interests immediately and continue to consider others. Rights may be entered when the Registrar forms the appropriate view.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I was half-way through a response to a question by Senator Harradine when we were interrupted by a dinner break I did not have. I had given a partial answer to the issue of being able to add rights and interests to a registered claim. What we are saying is that in relation to the particular right to negotiate process which would be in question it would only be those rights and interests which had passed this test at that time, and by the deadline, which would be able to be the subject of negotiation, or relevant, for that particular right to negotiate process. Once the claim was registered, in respect of any future section 29 notices or right to negotiate processes over future pro posed leases, the claim could be amended, based on application to the registrar to seek to have additional rights and interests satisfy the test.

speech.para: So it is not a complete bar for all time. The proposition that a right to negotiate process that was about to commence or had commenced—based on those rights and interests which passed this test—with the prospect that they could be added to at any time and with an invitation to claimants to seek to have them added to so they could become part of that right to negotiate process strikes us as unworkable. However, it does not foreclose on the opportunity to add those rights and interests to future right to negotiate processes in respect of that particular registered claim.

talk.start.para: —Is it possible for the government to indicate how it will be voting on the Harradine amendment?
—We will come to that.
—That is further down the track.
—Can we deal with the amendments seriatim?

—We are looking at the registration of claims and interests. With the registration test likely to be substantially higher than it is now, we are looking principally at the genuine potential native title holders. Under those circumstances, bearing in mind that where the registrar fails to register particular interests, registers some but not others, or another—say nine interests have been registered and one has not been registered because the material has not yet come to light—the question of whether that interest is a valid one goes to arbitration. What I think Senator Bolkus is pointing out with his N amendment is that, rather than it going to arbitration, once the information comes to light why can't the registrar simply register that particular interest?

—That is exactly the point that we are pursuing. We are talking about this in the context of a new framework of evidentiary requirements, documentation and so on. In a sense, what we are trying to achieve is some flexibility for the registrar, who could be in a position to proceed with some claims but may, for instance, have called for more information and may want more information in respect of some others. By being able to proceed with some and allow further consideration of the others it provides flexibility, recognising, as Senator Harradine rightly says, that we are talking of a much higher threshold in terms of the evidentiary test and the sort of information that is required.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The government is not able to accept the amendment, as I have stated. The current processes impose some discipline on claimants to identify those native title rights and interests which they believe will satisfy the prime facie test to make their claim, to allow the registrar a month to determine whether or not he or she is satisfied that there is a prime facie case in respect of those native title rights and interests.

speech.para: If we leave the process open there is very little discipline at all. It is for grantee parties, those seeking leases, licences, et cetera, that are subject to this process—and, remember, we are talking about thousands—to be exposed to the potential for the ball game changing in mid-course—that is, to have additional rights and interests in the middle of a right to negotiate process in this way. Subject to that sort of uncertainty, we do not think it is reasonable.

Claimants should identify those native title rights and interests which they claim and give the registrar the opportunity and the information required for him or her to satisfy themselves that it is a prima facie case. So far as that right to negotiate process is concerned, those are the rights and interests which will be able to be subject to negotiation as to the impact on them of the proposed lease or licence. Once the claim is registered, with respect to any future section 29 notices claims can be amended if additional evidence is brought that persuades the registrar that additional rights and interests should be registered. But I think you must take account of the other parties to a right to negotiate process and the certainty which they have every reason and right to seek as well.

talk.start.para: —Senator Harradine mentioned that this registration test is substantially higher than what was there previously. He said that this will mean that we will have only genuine native title claimants registering—
—I think I said `by and large'.

—Or by and large genuine native title claimants, as opposed to by and large non-genuine native title claimants, who may miss out as a result of this. Considering that the actual number of people who may miss out is unknown—who have a connection but miss out on the physical connection—and if the number of people lodging native title claims is slightly less but similar to what they are now, will we be back here in the Senate ratcheting the test up higher than it is now?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The parliament is now considering the benefit of having had four years experience of the current Native Title Act and with experience having found it inadequate, we earnestly hope and believe, and come to the parliament believing, that this test will be adequate. If the legislation is passed in the manner proposed by the government there will be no need to amend it.

speech.para: I would think that you would accept that all legislation of this kind must be subject to the test of practicality and workability. It is open to a future government, Labor or Liberal, to come back to the parliament at some point in time and seek to have any of these points changed in any way that it sees fit. It is for the parliament to make a decision. We believe that we have struck upon a test which is at a level at which it will work effectively and it should not be in need of amendment in the future.

talk.start.para: —Considering the statements that have been made by the government about the need to remove multiple claims, has the government made any estimate of how many people will be excluded or who will drop off the current claims as a result of these processes? I guess that is what you have promised your constituency—that they will see fewer people able to go through this process. What is your estimate of how many people will be knocked off the process as a result of the higher threshold test?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —Of course the government has not. We are setting the standard and it will be for the registrar to apply it. We ourselves are not seeking to apply this test to all the claims in the system. I remind you that the test will apply only to claims registered since the government's registration test was first introduced into the parliament. That is now some time ago. I think it was the end of June 1996 when we first introduced legislation regarding this test and we indicated then that the test would apply to all claims registered after that date. I think there were several hundred claims registered to that point which are not affected by this test per se, unless there is a section 29 notice issued in respect of them, so it will have a differential impact in terms of when the claim was registered, what it covers, et cetera. But, no, we believe that this test will do what many Aboriginal groups have sought—that is, to impose more discipline in the registration process to ensure that only those with bona fide genuine claims and claim groups will have access to the right to negotiate.

speech.para: I remember sitting down with the Waanyi representatives complaining about the problems in relation to the Century process. They said to us, `There are claimants involved in this right to negotiate process who should not be here. There should be a better test to ensure that they are not part of this registration process.' It was even said to us then that we ought to have a majority test in relation to the right to negotiate: that if a majority of registered claimants can reach agreement then the agreement should be signed. We are not doing that; we are not putting in a proposal of that kind. The right to negotiate still involves the necessity to get the agreement of all the claimants if you want to avoid going to arbitration.

But the test will minimise the extent to which there are several claims coming from within the one claim group. This is something sought by Aboriginal people to ensure that one claimant group makes one claim, and you do not have several claims being made by people who are all related and within the one claim group. We are confident that, as it is implemented and as claims are made, it will reduce the extent of the real problem within Aboriginal communities of multiple competing and overlapping claims often generated from within the one group and that the right to negotiate process, which we acknowledge is a very important process for Aboriginal people, will involve genuine claimants sitting down, discussing and seeking agreement with the proposers of the particular mining development.

talk.start.para: —The minister must have promised something to the bush in relation to this particular threshold measure. What have you actually said will be achieved numerically? Have you actually been advising mining interests and so on to get ready with their section 29 notices to re-establish the requirement to establish the right to negotiate?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —We have not promised or proposed anything in relation to numbers. That will be a matter for the registrar to determine in relation to the claims made. I cannot forecast or would ever endeavour to suggest whether any existing claims would be subject to this test or the extent to which they would pass or fail this particular registration test, remembering that their applications for determination for native title of course can proceed and are not affected by this test at all. This only relates to the right to negotiate and the government has not indicated to anyone, privately or publicly, how many of the claimants who are in the current system might or might not fail this test.
—I am just wondering, though, whether you have advised industry sectors to get ready with their section 29 notices.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I am not giving any advice to anybody. We are putting forward our legislation. We hope it will be passed. If and when it is passed, it is a matter for all those affected by it to act in accordance with it.

speech.para: Amendments (Senator Bolkus's) agreed to.
Amendment (Senator Minchin's), as amended, agreed to.

That means I will not be moving 224, 225 or 227. I ask that we could move those after the Senate has dealt with government amendment 73 and Senator Harradine's amendment N4.

speech.para: Amendments (by Senator Minchin) proposed:
(72) Schedule 2, item 63, page 203 (line 8), omit "accompanying documents", substitute "other documents provided by the applicant".
(73) Schedule 2, item 63, page 205 (line 22) to page 206 (line 28), omit subsections (5) to (10), substitute:

para.inline: Factual basis for claimed native title

speech.para: (5) The Registrar must be satisfied that the factual basis on which it is asserted that the native title rights and interests claimed exist is sufficient to support the assertion. In particular, the factual basis must support the following assertions:
(a) that the native title claim group have, and the predecessors of those persons had, an association with the area; and
(b) that there exist traditional laws acknowledged by, and traditional customs observed by, the native title claim group that give rise to the claim to native title rights and interests; and

(7) The Registrar must be satisfied that at least one member of the native title claim group:
(a) currently has or previously had a traditional physical connection with any part of the land or waters covered by the application; or

(b) previously had and would reasonably have been expected currently to have a traditional physical connection with any part of the land or waters but for things done (other than the creation of an interest in relation to land or waters) by:
(i) the Crown in any capacity; or
(ii) a statutory authority of the Crown in any capacity; or
(iii) any other person.

para.inline: No failure to comply with section 61A

speech.para: (8) The application and accompanying documents must not disclose, and the Registrar must not otherwise be aware, that, because of section 61A (which forbids the making of applications where there have been previous native title determinations or exclusive or non-exclusive possession acts), the application should not have been made.

para.inline: No extinguishment etc. of claimed native title

speech.para: (9) The application and accompanying documents must not disclose, and the Registrar must not otherwise be aware, that:

(a) to the extent that the native title rights and interests claimed consist of or include ownership of minerals, petroleum or gas—the Crown in right of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory wholly owns the minerals, petroleum or gas; or

(b) to the extent that the native title rights and interests claimed relate to waters in an offshore place—those rights and interests purport to exclude all other rights and interests in relation to the whole or part of the offshore place; or

(c) in any case—the native title rights and interests claimed have otherwise been extinguished (except to the extent that the extinguishment is required to be disregarded under subsection 47(2), 47A(2) or 47B(2)).

talk.start.para: —The question is that government amendment 72 be agreed to.

talk.start.para: —The question now is that government 73 be agreed to.

—Government amendment 73 is the kernel of this debate and, as we said earlier, the opposition does not support this amendment. This is the one that goes to the heart of the threshold test. I would like to suggest to the committee that it might be appropriate to put opposition amendment N36 before Senator Harradine's N4. I think the Democrats and Greens (WA) amendments 235 to 237 could, in essence, go first, but Senator Harradine's amendment and the opposition amendment are the ones that basically stand head to head against each other. From our position, it would obviously be much preferred if the opposition amendment were debated first. That is very much our first option, though the government position is one that we really could not accept.

—On several occasions, I have made the suggestion that we deal with what has been the debating point throughout this last hour or so—that is, we look at what the real choices are and, quite frankly, the numbers in the Senate are indicating what the real choices are. The Greens and the Democrats are indicating that there are not the numbers in the Senate to support N4, so I believe it would make sense for us to deal with government amendment 73, then deal with N4 and then deal with the other amendments, which in fact may be an improvement on those positions.

—Just briefly in support of what Senator Margetts has said, I think we always should move from the least desirable. —This seems to be an attempt by some people to try to weasel out of potential public commitments that have been made by parties in the public arena. I would be unkind enough to suggest that the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, in front of Australia, in front of the elders, signed up to the six steps to coexistence, and that included No. 3—respecting indigenous cultural and spiritual attachment to traditional lands. I am just wondering if what we are doing here is trying to organise the pattern so that that promise is broken by the ALP.
—Once again, the flak seems to be coming from this side of the parliament, and unjustifiably so.
—Oh, I don't know.

—Yes, you have your own interests here. I could argue with Senator Margetts at length, but the reality of the situation is that we are continuing with the amendment that we moved last time. It is an amendment which we hope will get support in the Senate, and it is the amendment that maintains the traditional attachment test, the Mabo test, the Brennan test in Mabo. speech.para: Blind Freddy understands that, if the numbers are not here for this one, the Senate has to make an assessment as to what the second best preference is, if it is concerned about protecting Aboriginal interests. If, to some, that second best preference is the government's position as opposed to Senator Harradine's, let them be judged on that. The commitment is there. The commitment stays there. But, in all your purity, if you want to vote Aboriginal interests down, Aboriginal rights down, Senator Brown, go ahead and do so.

As I mentioned earlier, there are some real hard cases out in the community, people who will move to different areas who will not qualify to pursue claims under Senator Minchin's test, who will qualify under ours and who will also qualify under Senator Harradine's. No matter how much blustering bombast that you throw at me, no matter how much rhetoric you indulge in for the next hour or so to try to argue that it is the Labor Party who is selling out, let me tell you that you are the one walking with your eyes open over the side of a cliff.

talk.start.para: —That does tempt me to my feet. I am not going to enter into any argument with Senator Bolkus. I have heard the heavyweight arguments coming from the ALP before. We have seen them try to browbeat us into agreeing to log forests. We have even seen them try to browbeat us into such ventures as the uranium mines, dams and so on.

speech.para: That is not what is germane here. Germane here is proper order. On the non-government benches, there has been a move to bring in a new amendment—that is, Senator Harradine's amendment—as against those we dealt with in December. The right and proper thing is to test that amendment before we go back to the position we had in December. We have made it quite clear that we will not be supporting that Harradine amendment. It does not make any difference which order it goes in, and let me make it quite clear why that is the case.

I am not going to be dictated to in selling out Aboriginal interests further by Senator Harradine or anyone else. The Labor Party can do that if they want to, there has to be a line drawn somewhere. If it is `brinkpersonship' that Senator Bolkus is engaged in here, it is not working. The proper order that Senator Margetts has put forward in dealing with these amendments should be the way we go. It does not matter. It is not going to change the voting outcome, and so be it.

Let me just reiterate that we have an alternative coming from Senator Harradine which is not just marginally different; it is vastly different, and it cuts out people who could make a claim. We can challenge each other all night as to which of the 800 potential claims come within or without the ambit of Senator Harradine's or Senator Bolkus's positions. All of us had a position in December on this issue which we said was the bottom line then, including Senator Harradine. Senator Harradine has drifted away from his bottom line. As far as I am concerned, he can drift on his own because there are people out there in the bush who lose out if we drift with him.

I will be saying a bit more later when it comes to the upgrade provisions and the right to negotiate over the upgrade of lands. I will not canvass that here because that is going to be a test in itself. So much has been sold out already, though. Of course the argument always comes up, `Oh, well, drift a little further.' Not on this one. We stated our position in December, Labor did, the Democrats did and Senator Harradine did. But Senator Harradine has now decided to renege, to give away more against the wishes and interests of the indigenous people. Be that on his head. The Labor Party can decide what it wants to do in its own good time.

talk.start.para: —I just want to remind the Senate that nobody has answered the question about how you deal with the difficulty of defining `parent' in Aboriginal culture, given the variety of Aboriginal culture; nobody has answered the question of how you deal with stolen generation adopted children; and nobody has answered how those cultural complexities will be dealt with in any way, shape or form by Senator Harradine's amendments. In effect, we have the Labor Party voting for a physical connection test. That is the bottom line of it.

—I think it is important that the Democrats put on the record where we stand in all of this. There is no doubt that the Labor Party's amendment is preferable to any of the others which have been proposed, at least in terms of the government and the Harradine amendments, and that would be about as far as the Democrats were prepared to go.

speech.para: The principle that we keep enunciating is that the registration test should include a physical or a spiritual or a cultural connection. We cannot see that Senator Harradine's and the government's position are very different. Certainly, in theory, Senator Harradine's amendment seems to be an improvement on the government's position, but we do not see that it is sufficiently an improvement to really attract us. Let me just say why that is so.

The problem with both the government and Senator Harradine's amendment is that the onus of proof is very much on people who are the victims of dispossession—in one sense not only of dispossession but also of attempted genocide. It seems to me that justice cannot be delivered when what most of these people have experienced has been without their knowledge and without their consent. I pointed out before that in Queensland particularly there has been a practice of destroying documents which could in fact establish some of the connections that either the government or Senator Harradine are talking about, but because of the loss of that documentation it is very doubtful. I have not heard Senator Harradine give me a guarantee that it could obtain. It is very doubtful that we could proceed down the road of the government or Senator Harradine's amendment and arrive at any justice for the people we are talking about.

We have information that suggests that people who have been dispossessed, or in fact stolen, in terms of the stolen children, may still have a cultural place held for them within the system of native title holding; not in any white law system, but certainly in terms of how Aboriginal people view it. That certainly is true of the Maroochy Barambah case that I detailed before dinner. Are we going to deny those people their connection? I believe that we cannot take that risk. Why should they have to have the onus of proof to prove their position over and against what was an immoral and an illegal action by governments and other people?

Just one more example, and I will close with this, is that in Victoria, from 1886 onwards, so-called half-castes were no longer permitted to live on mission stations. Yet they were set firmly within their own native title country. In a sense, it is a policy based on eugenics, I understand, Senator Brown, and we cannot place our trust in that kind of policy. So that is the position that we are left in and that is why we would prefer to deal with Senator Harradine's amendment first. But we are aware of how the numbers go in this place.

Senator MINCHIN

talk.start.para: —Madam Chair, I understood it was agreed that we would now move to government amendment No. 73 before moving to Senator Harradine's amendment N4. I understood that was the procedure that we all agreed on. Government amendment No. 73 reads:

speech.para: (73) Schedule 2, item 63, page 205 (line 22) to page 206 (line 28), omit subsections (5) to (10), substitute:

talk.start.para: —Senator Bolkus, you have an amendment to government amendment No. 73—N37.

speech.para: (N37) Section 190B(6), omit "some", substitute "one".
