talk.start.para: —I would like to make a couple of comments at this stage in respect of that vote and the next vote. All the way through this debate, the opposition has said that its preferred option is the one with three avenues of claim. That, of course, was defeated a few moments ago. I also said that our second preferred option was the Harradine proposal, which accommodates an extra generation of people. To get to the Senator Harradine proposal one had to ensure that there was something there to amend. Our support for the previous motion before the chamber lays the groundwork for us to pick up the Harradine amendment.

speech.para: The role of the amendments has meant that at some stage difficult decisions have to be made by us all. People made a difficult decision in respect of the opposition amendment. People had to make a difficult decision as to the government amendment to ensure that there was a platform to pursue the Harradine amendment as a second option. People now have to make a difficult assess ment as to whether to accept the Harradine amendment to the government proposal or to allow the government proposal to go through unamended.

It is very important that the Harradine amendment—which, as I said earlier, is a major improvement on the government's proposal and is a second best to our amendment in our eyes—now be carried by the Senate. Without going through the previous debate, I re-emphasise the point that a lot of people will be enfranchised by the Harradine amendment who would be disenfranchised if that amendment were not carried by the Senate. I hope that the numbers are there for it to be carried.

talk.start.para: —On a point of order: I draw your attention, Madam Chair, to the procedure whereby an amendment was made to the legislation and now we are being asked to deal with an amendment to that amendment.
—It is not an amendment to the amendment. Senator Bolkus was not correct. Senator Harradine's amendment is an addition.

—Thank you, Madam Chair, for your considerate response to my easygoing question! I just point out that you will have to resolve that with Senator Bolkus who just said that it is an amendment to the amendment.
—I think Senator Bolkus has just taken the point that I have made.

—My office has been looking through this, and Senator Harradine could not have made that amendment until that amendment was passed. In fact, Senator Harradine's amendment is an amendment to the amendment we have just passed.

—It is an addition to it; it is not altering the substance. I have been given advice that that is the case, and that is my understanding. I am calling Senator Harradine. Do you wish to disagree, Senator Margetts?
—I just suggest that when we have amendments which are in addition, we generally call them amendments.
—But they are additional; they are not altering the substance of the amendment that the government was moving.
—I move:

speech.para: (N4) Schedule 2, item 3, page 206, line 28, at the end of section 190B, add:

This amendment is an addition to the amendment to the Native Title Amendment Bill which has just been carried by the committee. I will not take long because we canvassed the matter in the amendment earlier today. I hope the government and the committee as a whole looks favourably on this particular measure. The government is insistent upon its test, but this ameliorates it so as to ensure that indigenous people who have been victims of the stolen generation and locked gates problems are not prevented from having their claims registered when they have not given up their native title rights and interests to the land of their ancestors.

After discussion, the government has gone some way—and I admit this—to providing for this situation in subsection (b) of the amendment that has just been passed by the committee. But in my view this does not go far enough, given the fact that many of the victims of those policies and incidents, due to the scandalously low life expectancy of indigenous people, are no longer alive. Hence, I am moving this additional amendment. I am doing so by adding an extra generation to the government's physical connection test. I commend the legislation to the committee and hope, notwithstanding what has been said thus far in the chamber, that honourable senators will realise that this is a very significant additional amendment to the Native Title Amendment Bill.

talk.start.para: —Madam Chair, I am not entirely sure at which point an amendment becomes a bill. Perhaps I could be advised at which point, when the Senate makes amendments, they become part of the bill.

speech.para: We will support, as we did last year, the Mabo test proposed by the ALP last year, as this is at least in accordance with common law principles. We do not agree that this common law position on determination should be applied at the registration stage, but in categorically ruling out support for any form of physical connection test we support the ALP compromise on a compromise. The ALP clearly have put their cards on the table in that, rather than supporting the threshold test which was put forward by the National Indigenous Working Group, they prefer the physical connection test.

talk.start.para: —Senator Bolkus, simply because you say that there is a massive difference between the government bill and Senator Harradine's amendment, does not make it so. I have to say that I just cannot see how you can make that claim. I really believe that Senator Harradine is not advancing us past where the government has left us, that is, with a physical connection, which will certainly rule out many people.

speech.para: I think that what Senator Harradine is doing is a slight improvement but that it breaks the absolute principle that we have been committed to and arguing about for so long, that is, that the connection should be physical or cultural or spiritual. Trying to convince us that somehow or other there is a vast gap between Senator Harradine's position and the government's position does not wash, I am afraid.

The problem is that I do not see how including a reference to a parent of a member of the native title claim group solves the problem of stolen children. Although they may know the group from which they came, the evidence is that many of them still do not know who their actual parents are, so we still have the problem. Then, of course, it does not address the problem of wholesale removals that go back much further than one generation. I really cannot understand, Senator Bolkus, how you can say that there is a massive gap between the government's position and Senator Harradine's position. It just does not wash with me, I am afraid, even though you may say it a number of times.

talk.start.para: —I agree with Senator Woodley. What has happened here is, firstly, that Senator Harradine's amendment removes all avenues for a connection with the land other than a physical one being a reason for a person to move towards a claim. It adds that a claim is taken to include a reference to a parent of a member of the native title claim group.

speech.para: That is a slight advance on the government's position, but it leaves out uncles, aunts and grandparents—all previous generations. What we see in this amendment is what is left, but we should be looking at what has been taken out. Beyond that, it very clearly does away with the spiritual connection, the cultural connection and the traditional connection that people have with the land unless they have a physical connection argument to put forward. It is just not good enough.

The dynamics of this are that, in December last year, the non-government participants in this debate agreed to have the spiritual, cultural and physical connection test available. All other components of the non-government benches except for Senator Harradine hold firm to that. That is for him to wrestle with. The Greens cannot go along with this further removal of the ability of indigenous people to make a claim that the land is theirs when it is.

Senator Minchin might talk about all the processes that are in between, but that confuses the matter. Let us be straight about it. If we stop people at the outset, we stop them at the finish; if we stop them at the gate, we stop them getting anywhere. The problem here is that, as Senator Woodley has put it, Senator Harradine's amendment is very close to the government's amendment. It is certainly much closer to the government's amendment than it is to the next Greens-Democrat amendment. That will be the real test here.

Senator Harradine's amendment has gone, as I said before—the numbers are not here for it. The real test will be whether the numbers are here for us to stick true with the test that we first supported in December last year.

talk.start.para: —I am getting advice that there still seems to be some concern about whether Senator Harradine's amendment is in fact valid, given the way the vote went, what it added on and what it changed. Could I ask the chair to go back and look to see whether in fact Senator Harradine's amendment will work.
—Senator Harradine's proposed amendment is valid. It is an addition of 190B(11) to the section that is already in the bill.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —To clarify matters, the Senate has adopted government amendment 73 which introduces the new physical connection test in subsection (7)(b). What Senator Harradine is proposing is an amendment which would amend the bill to add to the meaning of (7)(b) which is now part of the bill. What Senator Harradine is proposing is what is in addition to that, so that for the purpose of the operation of subsection (7)(b) the reference to a member of the native title claim group would be taken to include a reference to the parent or a member of the native title claim group. So it is an interpretation of (7)(b) which the committee has just adopted.

—I do not want to prolong this—I suppose I am prolonging it—but I think that Senator Margetts has a point. You see, it is not just adding; it is actually changing the government's registration test. That is why the government has indicated that it will vote against it. This is the point that I think Senator Margetts is trying to push. We know how the numbers are, so I do not intend to continue this, but you can see my problem with what is being said.

—The fact is that the committee has voted to add subclauses (5) to (10) and, once that has been achieved, it is quite within the competence of the committee to add another subclause—subclause (11). In that context, it is quite valid for the amendment to be made.
—I do not propose to respond to the statements that have been made. It is quite clear that Senator Brown is obdurate in his attitude to the truth in this matter.
—Mr Temporary Chair, on a point of order: I would like a retraction of that.
—There is no point of order, Senator Margetts.

—Mr Chairman, I rarely say those sorts of things. I make that point that before dinner I tried to outline, and Senator Bolkus and Senator Minchin both tried to outline, the facts of the situation. I ask honourable senators to focus on what Senator Brown said as to this amendment. If he wants me to show him how he is absolutely wrong in just a minimal understanding of what native title is all about, I shall be able to provide him with a little paper on it tomorrow, which I shall have incorporated into Hansard .
—It might have been my father who told me to be careful of anybody who thinks that they are the sole owners of the facts. We have a difference of opinion here.
—You should have listened to him.

—I did listen to him, and it is good advice. We have a difference of opinion here. Yes, I can be obdurate, I can stand strong when there is a further erosion of the rights of indigenous people involved in this pretty terrible process in here. We have not heard the last of it yet. We are going to see more of it. If `obdurate' is a word that Senator Harradine wants to levy, I will accept it. I am not in the business of simply going weak at the knees because he and I have different interpretations. I respect his ability to stand for what he thinks are the facts and I hope he will do likewise.

—On another matter altogether, I realise that something very sensitive is occurring in this debate and that is that without really due recognition—we have been talking about stolen children—I am conscious of the fact that we may have in the gallery some people who come under that heading. I would like to recognise them and say that we are not just talking about theory but about the lives of people, whose lives we affect deeply. I wanted to recognise that that is so.

—It is probably appropriate at this stage also to very briefly repeat a point I made earlier. We are talking about the difference between the Harradine amendment and the government's position. Earlier I mentioned the Wangkangurru people of the south-east corner of the Simpson Desert in western Queensland. They were removed in the 1940s. As I said earlier, they know their sites. They are a very traditional people. They have a traditional connection to their country. They are imbued with it. They associate themselves with it. I am informed that in all cases their parents have died. So, under the government test, they would not be able to pursue their claim; under the Harradine test they would. That is why I have been saying consistently that there is a big difference if you were to take it back one generation. It is the difference between two decades or maybe five, six or seven years. That in itself demonstrates, I think, the difference between the two tests. They are not the only ones. Earlier, we mentioned people from Great Keppel, and I am sure there are quite a number of similar circumstances.

speech.para: As I said earlier in the debate, our preferred position was the one that we moved and the one that did not get the support of this place. But in the same way that we have been trying to make incremental gains on what passed the parliament last year, trying to resist erosion of those gains or of the position that might have got through last year, in the same way that we make a commitment to ensure that the principles we pursue now we will pursue in government, I say to the committee that though this may not be the preferred option of some—obviously, our preferred option was the one we moved—I think it would be an enormous injustice to possibly a whole generation of people if we were not to pick up the amendment.

Senator Woodley, I think you have picked the right point again in terms of stolen generations. In a sense they are covered by the `locked out' provisions, but people have been locked out in more than one way, they have been driven out in more than one way. If we acknowledge that, I think we really have to acknowledge the Harradine position. Though I would maintain that it does not cover all situations, it does cover a whole lot more than the government's does. That is the reason we are supporting it.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Harradine's ) be agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: (237) Schedule 2, item 63, page 205 (line 27) to page 206 (line 24), omit subsections (6), (7), (8) and (9), substitute:

(6) If the Registrar is considering placing reliance on material which is adverse to the interests of the claimant, or inconsistent with material supplied by the claimant, the claimant must be shown the material and given a reasonable opportunity to respond or supply further material.

(7) If, after receiving a response or other material from the claimant, the Registrar is satisfied that there is a genuine factual dispute with respect to the adverse or inconsistent material or a genuine legal dispute as to its effect, the Registrar must not consider the adverse or inconsistent material further.

The government proposal does not require that evidence be filed with an application; merely that the factual basis be adequately described. The amendment deletes the new requirements which do not relate to the information required to be lodged with the application but retains the prime facie test in relation to material that must be lodged under section 190B.

The physical connection test is removed under section 190B(6). If the registrar is considering relying on material adverse to the claimant, the claimant must have a chance to respond. If after that there is a factual dispute the registrar must not consider the adverse material further under section 190B. The government's amendments seek to apply the new, more onerous registration test to all claims currently on the register of claims. We believe it is an unnecessary task. The National Indigenous Working Group proposed amendments focused on those instances where registration via a low threshold test may have caused problems—for instance, in overlapping claims in response to section 29 notices.

I indicate that because we have just passed amendments, including government amendment No. 73—and of course we have had discussions backwards and forwards on whether it is an amendment that has been moved or now the bill—it now means that the Greens-Democrats amendments need to be altered a little in line with the new situation. Therefore, where our amendment originally was to delete sections 6, 7, 8 and 9, I believe they will need to be renumbered 5, 7, 8 and 9. I am happy to be advised if that is not the case. This does give all participants in this debate a chance to reasssess the removal of the physical connection test. If it is believed, and it has been strongly argued by Senator Bolkus—I have to say that his arguments for his own amendments were not his most convincing—by the majority of members of this chamber that the physical connection test is not fair to indigenous people, this is the chamber's chance to address that.

speech.para: Also, subclause 9 under the amendment which was recently carried, provides for non-extinguishment of claim native title et cetera. As a consequence, we do not support them.

talk.start.para: —I am prepared to look at alternatives to that proposal. If Senator Bolkus is saying that he would support the removal of 7 and 8, perhaps I could get an answer from him as to whether that would be acceptable to him by way of amendment instead of 5, 7, 8 and 9.

—What I am saying is that this really is not all that well thought out by the Democrats and Greens. There are intended and unintended consequences which go far in excess of what we contemplated and passed last time, and what we would be contemplating passing this time. Basically, a bit more thought to this might have worked out a more positive outcome, but to try to move these amendments now is a bit like crying over spilt milk.
—The milk was spilt when the opposition agreed to a physical connection test. Very nice trying to blame it on the Greens now; it is not working, Senator Bolkus. I move:

talk.start.para: —Greens (WA)-Democrats amendment 327A is to oppose part 4, item 11—that is, the retrospective elements. I am sure we have heard on many occasions people arguing about the injustice of retrospectivity. Here we want to remove the ability of people to retrospectively knock out claims on the basis of what many people have argued is wrong in terms of physical connection tests. Therefore, I implore the committee, I implore the Labor Party, I implore Senator Harradine and I implore all senators to remove the retrospectivity involved in this and they can do that by opposing part 4, item 11.
—I support amendment 327A, together with amendment 328. I think Senator Margetts's amendment was deliberated upon last time and we hope it is possible to get it up this time.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —Obviously the government does not support this amendment. We first moved the proposed new registration test at the end of June 1996 by way of the introduction of a bill into the House of Representatives. What is proposed is not retrospective. It was made clear then that the new registration test would apply to all claims made after that date. That is absolutely the norm for many government actions and proposals. It certainly applies to all budget proposals. Notice was given by way of the introduction of that test then that all future claims would be subject to the new registration test, so it is not retrospective.

speech.para: We now have over 700 claims in the system. Many of them, of course, are causing the very problems which indigenous groups and others have sought to have remedied by the application of a new registration test. So it makes a nonsense of the whole proposal, and I would have thought the ALP would recognise that it makes a nonsense of all of this if every single claim that is currently in the system—some 750, covering nearly 50 per cent of Australia—is immune from this test. We have all been wasting our time if that is the proposition.

talk.start.para: —Can I just get some clarification from Senator Margetts. The amendment you said you were moving was No. 328. If it is not that, there is some validity in Senator Minchin's argument. But it is No. 328, is it not?

—The amendment that I am moving is No. 327A to remove the retrospectivity, and No. 328 later replaces it with a better option. It is a bit hard to replace it until we remove the existing section, so that is what we will be attempting to do.

speech.para: Quite frankly, I think it is despicable to treat human rights as if it were a sales tax bill. If this is what the government is suggesting is the right thing to do, perhaps next time there is a business related bill which is not a tax bill we will see if the government treats people the same way and see what kind of response it gets. I do not think it is the right thing to do, and I thought for an instant that Labor was going to support removing that section to be replaced by No. 328. There is not a lot of point in moving No. 328 unless we have opposed the existing section. Perhaps I could get some clarification on what the opposition's position is on No. 327A to oppose item 11.

talk.start.para: —Our position is that No. 328 is an acceptable alternative. But looking at No. 327A, once again, to get the full ramifications of that, my understanding is that last time we did not adopt a measure like No. 327A, but we adopted the regime as reflected in No. 328. My other information is that, if the Democrat-Greens (WA) amendment No. 327A is not successful, the Democrat-Greens would move reconsideration of item 11 and move No. 328. So my information is that there is not incompatibility between not supporting No. 327A and supporting No. 328. I will double check that while the debate continues, but that is the starting point that we have.

Therein, you will notice that the Democrat-Greens (WA) amendment puts in a whole new registration regime. I move:

speech.para: (328) Schedule 5, item 11, page 347 (line 16) to page 351 (line 11), omit subitems (3) to (11), substitute:

para.inline: Application accepted for registration after 27 June 1996

speech.para: (3) If an application was registered after 27 June 1996 in relation to land or waters that have not been the subject of a notice under section 29 of the old Act, or a corresponding provision of a law of a State or Territory covered by a determination under subsection 43(1) of the new Act or old Act, the relevant Minister of the State or Territory in which the land or waters are situated may request the Registrar to deal with the application or any part of it under the new Act.
(4) If the Registrar agrees to accept the request under subitem (3) or a part of it, the Registrar must:
(a) refer the request to the applicant and the representative body for the area concerned; and

(b) advise the applicant and the representative body that the representative body may, within 60 days after the request is referred, certify in accordance with its certification functions (see section 203BE) the application or part identified by the Registrar (subject to any amendment made by the applicant and considered by the representative body); and

(c) if the application or part is not certified by the representative body within that period, or within a further period agreed between the Registrar and the representative body—consider the application under section 190A of the new Act.
(5) If, at the commencement of this Act, there is more than one application on the Register in relation to the same area of land or waters, the Registrar must:
(a) consider whether the native title rights and interests claimed may consistently be held by different native title groups; and
(b) as soon as is reasonably practicable, advise the applicants and the representative body or bodies for the area of his or her view and of the reasons for that view; and

(c) request them to provide information and submissions as to whether it is appropriate for the expeditious conduct of the applications and the processes of the Act that the applications be amalgamated in whole or in part; and
(d) consider any information or submissions supplied pursuant to the request; and
(e) determine whether it is appropriate for the applications to be amalgamated, in whole or in part.
(6) If the Registrar decides that it is appropriate that the applications be amalgamated, in whole or in part, the Registrar must:
(a) advise the applicants and the representative body or bodies for the area of that fact; and
(b) request the applicants to amend their applications so as to ensure that:
(i) rights and interests that are common between the groups are the subject of only one application; and
(ii) separate rights and interests are the subject of other applications;
but only to the extent that the native title group concerned in relation to the separate rights and interests is different from the native title group in relation to the common rights and interests.
(7) If the Registrar notifies the applicants and the representative body or bodies referred to in subitem (6):

(a) the applicants must, within 60 days after receiving the notification, advise the Registrar whether they have been able to reach agreement as to the identity of the appropriate applicant for those rights and interests and, if they have, advise the Registrar which single application is to remain on the Register in relation to those rights and interests; and

(b) if, within that period or a longer period allowed by the Registrar, the applicants have not reached agreement, the Registrar must advise the representative body for the relevant area of that fact.

(8) If the representative body receives an advice under paragraph (7)(b), it must attempt by conciliation to obtain agreement between the applicants as to the identity of the appropriate applicant, and the appropriate description of the native title group on whose behalf the application is made, for the rights and interests.
(a) the representative body is not able to achieve a resolution within 6 months of the matter being referred to it by the Registrar; and
(b) either:
(i) it is satisfied that a resolution is not likely to be achieved within a reasonable time; or

(ii) a notice under section 29 of the new Act, or a corresponding provision of a law of a State or Territory covered by a determination under subsection 43(1) of the new Act, is lodged in relation to any part of the land or waters concerned;
the representative body must refer the matter to the arbitral body within 14 days.
(10) If the representative body does not refer the matter to the arbitral body, any applicant may do so.
(11) If the matter is referred to the arbitral body, the arbitral body must determine:
(a) which applicant is to act for the whole of the area covered by the applications in relation to which common rights and interests are claimed (if that applicant consents to act); and

(b) redefine the native title group so that, to the greatest extent possible, those who were otherwise covered by the overlapping applications are members of the native title group of the remaining application.

(11A) If, under this item, a particular applicant and a set of native title rights and interests are defined, the Registrar must amend one application accordingly and remove the other applications from the Register or amend them so that they are limited to rights and interests not the subject of the common application.

(11B) If a notice is given under section 29 before the Register is varied under subitem (11A), except with the consent of the negotiation parties (which for this purpose includes each of the native title parties at the date on which the section 29 notice was given) the negotiations must not commence, and the relevant period specified in section 35 does not commence to run.
(11C) If an application is required to be dealt with under subitems (3) and (4), and subitem (5), it should be dealt with first under subitem (5).

(iv) any other interest created in relation to particular land or waters, if at the time an interest covered by subparagraph (ii) or (iii) is in effect in relation to the land or waters; or
(10) Schedule 1, item 49, page 141 (after line 3), at the end of section 249C, add:

para.inline: Regulations to cover exclusive possession interests only

speech.para: (3) Before the Governor-General makes a regulation for the purposes of paragraph (1)(b) declaring a particular interest to be a Scheduled interest, the Minister must be satisfied that the interest confers a right of exclusive possession that extinguishes all native title rights and interests over the land or waters concerned.

Government amendment 3 will replace subsection 23B(9) with a new subsection that ensures that certain acts, including grants specifically for the benefit of Aboriginal people, are excluded from the confirmation of extinguishment provisions. Government amendment 4 rectifies a gap in the confirmation of extinguishment provisions by enabling a state or territory to confirm the effect of previous exclusive possession acts and previous non-exclusive possession acts that took place over land that now forms part of that state or territory but did not at the time the grant was made. Amendments 5 to 7 make minor amendments to section 47A to ensure that that provision, which enables certain extinguishing acts to be ignored when a native title claim is being determined, applies to areas which have been granted or vested, whether on trust or otherwise, expressly for the benefit of indigenous people.

Government amendment No. 8 replaces the word `declaration' in section 47B with the word `dedication', simply to ensure that the terminology used in 47B to refer to land reserved for a purpose is consistent with the terminology used elsewhere in the bill when referring to reserved land. Both amendments 9 and 10 affect the definition of `scheduled interest' set out in proposed section 249C in the bill: the grant of a scheduled interest before 23 December 1996 can be confirmed to have extinguished native title.

We are putting these amendments in good faith. We think they should be supported by the Senate; the confirmation regime was passed through the Senate last time. These amendments do pick up some anomalies which we have identified in discussions with all the other parties and with the various interests. While there may be those in the chamber who do not like the confirmation provisions at all, I would have thought they would see these as acceptable and sensible improvements to the confirmation regime.

talk.start.para: —The opposition had enormous problems with this extinguishment regime last time and those problems really have not gone away. The government here has undertaken a speculative exercise of attempting to predict what the courts may decide about the extinguishing effect of inconsistent grants of interest on native title.

speech.para: The government describes this section as confirmation of extinguishment, implying that these provisions merely confirm the common law position. However, it is clear to all of us on this side of the debate that these provisions do in fact overreach the common law and in themselves are legislative extinguishment of native title. The government, for instance, says that people have assumed that such interests as freehold, all types of leases, public works, et cetera, extinguish native title. But I think it is clear to say that the Wik decision left this assumption in a very unclear situation. The government says it needs to make clear which interests extinguish native title. However, this is very much a bad description of the effect of its legislation. It is misleading.

The process, for instance, by which the government has unilaterally determined what will extinguish native title is shoddy. It was exposed as such by parliamentary committee after parliamentary committee, and the process will result in the extinguishment of native title throughout the country with consequent compensation implications for the taxpayer. This is a provision that also rejects the principle adopted by Wik: the principle of coexistence. In terms of the general outline of this provision, what we have here are bucketloads of extinguishment: we have them by way of division 2B for instance.

The only justification for a legislative extinguishment regime is to allow development and interest to be granted over land without having to consider native title at all. To us, that is unacceptable. Extinguishment is not necessary for validation of titles or protection of the existing valid interests in the land. These interests do prevail already over native title; case after case has indicated that as well. What we have here is legislation with a sole purpose of ensuring that future interests can take place unimpeded in any way by native title. What we have here is not just extinguishment; we have discriminatory extinguishment. We have extinguishment also when, as I said, the common law leaves open whether it is suspension or extinguishment.

As I said, the principles of the Wik case are overturned by this particular part of the government's 10-point plan. The government, for instance, has attempted to ensure that native title will be partially extinguished by the grant of a non-exclusive possession act, a pastoral lease. Recognising this injustice, the Senate voted last December in favour of the amendments by Senator Harradine which confirmed the position at common law—namely, that native title is suppressed and not extinguished by the grant of a pastoral lease. We continue to support those amendments. When one looks at what extinguishes native title, when one looks at what the government has tried to ensure extinguishes native title, one finds a long, exhaustive list of interests such as rifle ranges, Defence purposes and water tanks. It is amazing to what extent the government has gone to find ways of extinguishing native title.

We say now that there still needs to be a focus on the government's approach to legislative extinguishment. We say the government still exceeds the common law. The claim that division 2B is intended to reflect the common law is still wrong. For instance, section 23J gives that game away. Section 23J says that compensation is payable where the legislation goes beyond the common law and extinguishes native title. It is a safety net provision but one that basically is a confession by the government that they go in excess of the common law.

In relation to the schedule of extinguishing interests, Senator Minchin says there are some 60,000 leases in division 2B, many of them in the schedule. Yet the way that schedule was drawn up, the way people's native title rights were extinguished on such a massive scale behind—as we found out—closed doors was in direct violation of the methodology made painstakingly clear by the High Court in the Wik decision. The judges of the court said that, when you are dealing with people's property rights and asking the extinguishment question, you must look carefully, firstly, at the legislation which authorises Crown grants; secondly, at the individual lease documents given to land holders to ascertain the precise rights; and, thirdly, at the native title rights which the local people assert over the land.

It is only then that you can come to a conclusion about inconsistency and extinguishment. But the Native Title Act left the extinguishment question to the courts and the common law to decide on a fair and just basis according to law. This government's proposal has ignored the detail of what was demanded by the court. Basically what we have here is a check list which will, I am sure, throw up error after error.

The other important aspect in this debate is the question of constitutional validity. Eminent lawyer after eminent lawyer has told parliamentary committees that lack of notification associated with division 2B acquisitions of property was a matter of constitutional concern. If indigenous Australians are not notified before their property rights are acquired and they are not given an opportunity to object, how can the bill be said to provide just terms and pass the procedural aspects of the just terms constitutionality test?

We continue to say the government's earlier overreach is a concern. The government, as Senator Minchin has said, is moving amendments. Some amendments will curtail the overreach in one of two ways. Subsection 9 of 23B will be widened so that it excludes all the appropriate forms of beneficial land ownership and trust or for the benefit of indigenous people, and areas created by divesting or grants to protect the national environment such as national parks have been excluded. These are beneficial amendments. As a consequence, we will support them.

Our amendments still go to the protection against overreach, for instance, in the definition of previous exclusive possession act. We also go to the question of 23B and the extinguishment as well. I say at this stage that the Greens-Democrats amendment to oppose division 2B is one that we will support when it comes up for a vote. We supported it last time, but, as the Senate knows, we were beaten by the numbers in that respect.

I also say that we have taken the government and the High Court at their word in respect of factors that are relevant in terms of section 23B and defining acts which the government says extinguish native title. Proposed subsection 9B excludes from the definition of a previous exclusive possession act a category of act which, in our view, cannot be included on any fair or reasonable basis. It excludes leases which exceed 25,000 hectares. The High Court said in Wik that the size of the lease in question was a very relevant consideration in deciding whether a particular grant extinguishes native title. In fact, even the government agrees. It lists size as one of the 10 relevant factors in its explanatory memorandum.

Taking the government and the High Court to word, we say that 25,000 hectares is a very large area in anyone's language. It is impossible how anyone could argue that every lease of that dimension would necessarily require exclusive possession in order to give effect to the grant. Excluding such grants does not mean that individual lease holders of large properties are prevented from proving in court that their particular grant necessarily implies exclusive possession. It simply means that we want to protect against the government sweeping every one of these very large grants indiscriminately into the extinguishing category.

There are other amendments as well which we will pursue, but, as I say, there are both constitutional and fairness problems in respect of the government's proposals put up the first time and also put up this time. We will be pursuing amendments once again to ensure that we protect the position that was passed in the Senate last year.

talk.start.para: —The opposition's amendment is quite ridiculous. They want to remove certain lease holders from the definition of exclusive possession simply on the basis of the size of the lease. They are taking it upon themselves to set an arbitrary figure of 25,000 hectares. I do not know how they reached 25,000 hectares. Why not make it 40,000 hectares? Why not make it 50,000 hectares? If it is an exclusive possession, it is exclusive possession. Exclusive possession is not determined by the size of the lease. I think they have simply plucked a number out of the air. If there is one lease in Queensland that is 25,000 hectares exactly and there is another one that is 25,000.82 hectares—0.82 hectares is about the size of a normal household block; and the person that is sitting on the 25,000 hectares is probably out too—
—Twenty-five thousand hectares is a normal block? Do you live in Texas?

—I said 0.82 of a hectare. One lease is 25,000 hectares and the other is 25,000.82 hectares. You take an arbitrary figure and the people who fall on one side of the line are in and the other ones are out.

speech.para: A perpetual lease is a perpetual lease and it is not determined by the size; it is determined by the way the lease was issued. Those leases—of 25,000 hectares and more—have been included in the exclusive possession schedule. I cannot see any reason why some arbitrary decision would be made to exclude anything over 25,000 hectares. It really has no bearing on the connection to the Wik decision at all. There were two test cases on the leases in Wik: one was 289,820 hectares and the smaller one was 138,560 hectares. They are a long way from the 25,000 hectares that the government has decided to put in the category of native title.

I think it is a quite silly and stupid amendment. I do not know how the figure of 25,000 was reached. Perhaps Senator Bolkus might tell us the way he reached it. Did he look into a crystal ball or did he come up with it some other way?

talk.start.para: —There is some clarification I need from Senator Bolkus in relation to opposition amendment N3. There is some conflict with Greens-Democrats amendment 12A. I would like to ask him—and I hope he has time to answer—what is the effect of opposition N3? What would be the reason for not supporting our 12A instead? N3 seems to be extinguishing crown to crown grants on titles that come under a number of categories, including residential and other categories. I wonder if Senator Bolkus can explain the rationale for not supporting 12A instead of his N3.

—Very briefly, as Senator Margetts rightly said, N3 is a modified version of an amendment which passed the Senate last year. It is an amendment which again corrects the overreach in the definition of a `previous exclusive possession act'. It excludes, for instance, grants of an interest between different arms of what is the same basic entity—for instance, crown to crown—whether it be a statutory authority or a state or federal government. It applies the same exclusion of the criteria of vesting of an interest in land in the same entities. Proposed subsection 9A of 23B also contains an appropriate protection where the land is subsequently put to residential, agricultural or commercial uses. At this point the exclusion no longer applies.

speech.para: The amendment also leaves it to the common law to determine what effect on native title those transfers between different arms of government—crown to crown—have. It is something that I think we pursued last time. We did not want to preclude a non-extinguishment capacity by adopting the extinguishment principle adopted by the government. It also maintains consistency with the current Native Title Act, which excluded these interests from the automatic extinguishment category.

So the advice is that, in essence, it does what we set out to do last time, but it has been amended probably more in style than anything else to pick up some of the technical problems with it. Given the fact that it is 45 seconds before 9.50 p.m. now, I should take on notice any further information which would clarify the modification. As I say, the substance is the same. It is an amendment which was developed by the indigenous working group lawyers and ourselves in consultation with other parties. My understanding is that, in essence and in substance, it does no different to what was passed last time. If I can talk for five more seconds and take the rest of the answer on notice for tomorrow morning, that would probably be a fair conclusion to the day's proceedings.
Progress reported.

talk.start.para: —I want to take a couple of minutes of the Senate's time tonight to speak of a great Australian who passed away recently. The former mayor of Mount Isa Franz Born died during the week of 27 March and was buried in Caloundra. He was the mayor of Mount Isa from 1975 to 1985 and was involved in a number of significant community projects, including the construction of the Mount Isa Civic Centre and library and Lake Julius.

speech.para: Through the auspices of the North West Star newspaper I have learnt of some of the tributes paid to the late Franz Born by friends and community leaders, including the current mayor Ron McCullough, Mr Fred Binzer and Mr Joe Schmider who gave some overview of the work that Mr Born did in the north-west during his time. Franz Born will be remembered as a great citizen of Mount Isa and of the north-west. A perfectionist in all he did, Mr Born came to Mount Isa in the early 1950s, travelling on a motorbike via dirt roads, after he had emigrated from Germany.

Attracted by the employment prospects, he took up a position as an underground miner and quickly progressed to foreman before leaving the mine to set up Mount Isa's brickworks—the first in Mount Isa. The business still survives in that city. He also built the Sunset Shopping Centre, which he used as a base for his smallgoods factory. That factory enabled him to draw on the skills he had learned as an apprentice butcher in Germany.

Mr Born was instrumental in the establishment of the Concordia Club in Mount Isa, which celebrated the strength of the German-Austrian migrant community in that city. His community service was recognised with the presentation of a Class 4 badge of merit by the Federal Republic of Germany during his time in Mount Isa. His entry into local politics as mayor of that mining city in the north-west was a logical progression of his community commitment.

I first met Franz Born in the early 1980s. Regrettably, I met him only very briefly when he was elected to the Liberal Senate team in Queensland at that time. He was not successful, being a little way down the ticket, but I often think that it was probably because of the influence that he and his supporters in the north had at that time in getting him on to the ticket that eventually led to my election, coming from the north, to lead the Liberal Party Senate team from Queensland.

After Franz Born left the mayoralty of Mt Isa, he moved to Caloundra in semi-retirement but continued his interest in local politics there. He was involved in the Caloundra Shire Council for several years. I am told he spent two terms there and my colleague Mr Peter Slipper, the member for the federal electorate that takes in Caloundra, has told me that Mr Born was well remembered for the distinctive and attractive design work that was done in Bullcock Street, one of the main city centre streets in Caloundra. A smallgoods manufacturing plant that he started on the Sunshine Coast is still operating and, despite changing hands, has maintained its original name of Franz Smallgoods.

Mr Born is survived by his wife Cobi and children Sonja, Brigitte, Martina and Frank. I think that the Senate should recognise the work of a great Australian, a person who did a tremendous amount of work in the north and north-west for his community and for the region generally. I extend, I am sure on behalf of all Queensland senators and, in fact, on behalf of senators generally, my condolences to his wife and family.

Madam President, in the couple of extra minutes of time left available to me, I would like to mention to senators a matter that I know will be of great importance to them—and I am sure they already know about it—and that is that 21 March of this year marked the 50th anniversary of Australia's research expeditions to Macquarie Island in the Great Southern Ocean.

Macquarie Island is a sub-Antarctic island located in the Southern Ocean at a latitude of 54 degrees 30 minutes south and 158 degrees 57 minutes east. It is 1,500 kilometres south-east of Tasmania and 1,300 kilometres north of the Antarctic continent. Macquarie Island is 34 kilometres long and five kilometres wide at its widest point. It has a total surface area of 128 square kilometres. It is part of the state of Tasmania and is a state reserve managed by the Tasmanian Parks and Wildlife Service.

Discovery of the island is attributed to Captain Frederick Hasselborough who on the brig Perseverance sighted it whilst on a sealing voyage out of Sydney in July 1810. It was named after the then governor of New South Wales, Lachlan Macquarie. This discovery was to lead to extensive exploitation of the local fauna and by the end of that year bases had been established on the island to take fur seals for their skins and elephant seals for their oil. These commercial activities had a devastating effect on the seal and penguin populations, with some species still recovering.

During Sir Douglas Mawson's visit from 1911 to 1914, the first scientific station was established on the island and, in addition to conducting geomagnetic observations and mapping the island, studies were made of the island's botany, zoology, meteorology and geology. The Macquarie Island expedition also established the first radio link between Australia and Antarctica by setting up a radio relay station on Wireless Hill that could communicate with Mawson's main expedition group at Commonwealth Bay and also with the Australian mainland.

The island was declared a wildlife sanctuary in 1933 and, with the establishment of the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Service in 1971, became a conservation area. It was upgraded to a state reserve in 1972 and in 1978 was renamed the Macquarie Island Nature Reserve. The Howard government nominated Macquarie Island for inscription on the World Heritage List in June 1996 and the nomination, which was made jointly with the Tasmanian government, was actually inscribed on the World Heritage List on 3 December 1997.
Macquarie Island is the oldest continuously occupied ANARE station below 50 degrees south.
Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I know you are very interested in this, Senator Ray.
—I am; I am paying attention.

—We as Australians can be proud of the work that is undertaken at Macquarie Island and elsewhere by members of Australia's Antarctic program. The research work undertaken in some of the world's most difficult conditions is both of international and of practical importance. I was pleased to be able to participate in the commemoration of this significant anniversary of one of the world's most remote and special places. It was with some pride that, on behalf of the Australian government and the Australian people—by telecommunications, because I was not there myself—I unveiled on 21 March 1998 a plaque commemorating the 50th anniversary of the station. I commend the great work that all the expeditioners who have worked for Australia over those years have done in that very remote place. It is one of the places that we are very proud of, and I am sure all senators join with me in congratulating all of those who have served on Macquarie Island over the past 50 years.

—This morning, there was a special hearing of the Senate Economics Legislation Committee to consider whether or not a senior officer of the Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business, Mr Derren Gillespie, had deliberately misled the committee in August last year. Before asking the committee to consider the matter, I provided the relevant material to the Clerk of the Senate and received the following advice:

speech.para: . . . the extracts from the evidence which you quote appear to indicate that there is ground for concluding that at least contradictory evidence was given, and perhaps that misleading evidence was given at last year's hearing.
He advised that there were two options: the committee could seek by further inquiry to clarify the apparent contradiction in the evidence; or the matter could be raised as a matter of privilege.

I chose the first option as the most appropriate step. Unfortunately, this morning's proceedings have failed to clarify the situation. However, before deciding whether I wish to take this matter further, I will consider the Hansard of this morning's hearing when it is available. The evidence in question was given by Mr Gillespie to the economics committee on 18 August 1997. For the information of the Senate, I will go through the relevant sections of the Hansard. On page E82, Mr Gillespie said:
I think the plain fact of the matter is that within the portfolio of Transport and Regional Development there is a contract let to some work, the details of which I am certainly not alive to.

I note that Mr Gillespie uses the term `alive to' to mean `aware of', and we had established that in the hearings of the committee. To continue, in evidence given to the same committee earlier this year, we were told that Mr Gillespie attended a presentation to the department on the first ACIL report in 1996.

We now know that a presentation was given by an ACIL representative on 9 September 1996. Departmental officers present at the briefing were Dr David Rosalky, Rex Hoy and Derren Gillespie. Mr Gillespie now tells us that he thought the questions were about the terms of the contract not the work to be done. That is, he thought the questions were about the actual terms of the contract signed by the consultant, however we already knew that information. That is how we found out that ACIL was doing this work. The Department of Transport and Regional Development had provided that information in answer to a question on notice about consultancies it had let. In August last year, Mr Gillespie was asked:
To your knowledge does the ACIL plan fit within the terms of the Workplace Relations Act or does it contemplate action outside the legislative framework?
He replied:
I do not have any insights into any of the work that ACIL may have done under that contract.

Again, how does that fit with the fact that Mr Gillespie attended the presentation by ACIL on its work on 9 September 1996? How does that fit with Mr Gillespie actually reading the report in the offices of the department? The Department of Transport and Regional Development has now advised that on 23 December 1996, Mr Gillespie was permitted to access the report and a room in which he could peruse the document was provided. Officers did not permit him to copy the report or to remove it from the area.

Any reasonable interpretation of this evidence suggests that his claim to have no insight into the work that was done under the ACIL contract just cannot be accepted—not how much the contract was worth, not who did the work, but what the consultancy actually involved and how that fitted in with the work he was doing. I remind the Senate that Mr Gillespie received a full briefing by the ACIL consultant—I assume David Trebeck—on 9 September 1996.

Mr Gillespie also participated in a meeting called to discuss the government's waterfront strategy on 16 December 1996. That meeting was attended by the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, Mr Reith, the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Sharp, and representatives from stevedore companies. I find it hard to believe that the details of the ACIL report were not discussed at that meeting.

Mr Gillespie read the ACIL report in the offices of the Department of Transport and Regional Development on 23 December 1996. He was given the report and a room in which to read it. Mr Gillespie advised that he thought the questions related to the second ACIL contract. That consultancy was not completed at the time that Mr Gillespie gave this evidence. I now go to the next reference in Mr Gillespie's evidence. In August last year, he told the committee:
I am not alive to any detail of any strategy that might be being developed.

We now know that, on 27 February 1997, the minister's office was provided with a copy of what Mr Gillespie described in a minute sent to the minister on 10 March as `the waterfront paper prepared by officials'. Later in the minute he said:
As the strategy paper noted, a dispute—of itself—would not produce desired change on the waterfront.
He also stated:
Attachment C deals with the termination of the workforce; this paper is included in the strategy document prepared by officials.
Later he says:
. . . you might identify matters that might be further worked up such as detailed strategies for achieving significant workforce change; . . .

That minute to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, dated 10 March 1997, was signed by Mr Gillespie as `Assistant Secretary Industry Strategy Team'. In August last year, he told the committee that he had no knowledge of any strategy that was being developed, and yet six months earlier he had provided his minister with a strategy paper. Mr Gillespie called it a strategy paper in a minute to the minister which he signed off personally.

Mr Gillespie was the officer in the department who was actually developing the strategy. His explanation was that he thought the questions about a strategy related only to work under way under the ACIL 2 contract. Of course, the questions did not. ACIL 1 and ACIL 2—as they are now known—are two parts of a single consultancy. ACIL 1 was to provide advice regarding an industrial relations strategy for the implementation of waterfront reform commenced in May 1996 and finished in August of that year. ACIL 2 followed on from that consultancy. It commenced in June 1997 and finished in October.

Mr Gillespie's strategy paper must have been built around the first ACIL report. He had been briefed on the report, he had read the report and he had attended a meeting with ministers, consultants, advisers and stevedores to discuss the strategy. It would appear almost impossible to separate out the ACIL 2 consultancy in relation to questions about a strategy, but Mr Gillespie claims that that is exactly what he did.

There is one other matter I wish to address concerning the government's waterfront strategy. It was confirmed this morning that the Department of Transport and Regional Development participated in the development of the waterfront strategy paper provided to Mr Reith on 27 February 1997. The document was developed progressively by senior officers from both departments. I have been advised that Mr Gillespie amended that strategy paper agreed with the transport department officers—I assume Dr Feeney and Mr Bills, the two senior officers in the maritime transport area—and provided it to Mr Reith (again, I assume, as an agreed paper) without further discussion with or reference to those transport officers.

I have also been advised that Mr Gillespie amended the strategy paper by deleting one of the strategy options and increasing the attractiveness of the confrontationist option; the option that encouraged the use of the provisions of the Workplace Relations Act and the Trade Practices Act to achieve the sacking of the MUA work force and the financial ruin of the MUA. I have been further advised that Mr Gillespie pushed this option in the course of his participation with Dr Webster, other consultants and political advisers in many meetings with stevedores and other employers.

It seems to me that Mr Gillespie has put himself in a difficult position. He has become an active player in what is basically a political campaign by the government against the MUA and the ACTU. It is therefore difficult for me as a politician to separate him from that political process. There are also a number of people who have a detailed understanding of this whole process from the letting of the first ACIL contract on. These people are apparently keen to see the truth come out. If more information about this exercise is provided, it will quickly be exposed. In my opinion, this issue still has a long way to go.

This technique could have been used to justify fake travel allowance claims, but seeing it has some history, one cannot imagine it had been done for that purpose. The only purpose for which I could imagine it was done is for taxation purposes. In many cases, members of parliament travelling, but not on one of the requirements to attract travel allowance, may in fact put those claims in against their own taxation forms because it is expenditure on parliamentary business, presumably—in this case probably not—and can in fact be taken off the tax.

I am going to take the weak option; I am not going to name the two members of parliament concerned, but I do think their colleagues might have a yap about and might drop broad hints that this should be taken off the hard drive, as Senator Faulkner says, and that this particular practice should cease. What will happen in the end is that they will get caught and then all people here—and none of those in the chamber at the moment are involved in this—will get the backwash of this particular scam. It is also a gross misuse of the facilities provided to members of parliament to put them to this particular purpose.

My informant has been reliable on everything else so I would not think he is unreliable on this particular matter. The matter was a subject of a complaint to the officials of the Queensland branch of the Liberal Party. The person who took that complaint is now in a new job courtesy of the patronage of the Queensland branch of the Liberal Party and, therefore, would probably no longer be willing to give evidence on this particular matter but certainly raised it with my informant in great detail amongst other complaints, others of which I do not regard as terribly relevant to our proceedings here tonight. It might be a good idea in their party room at some stage for one of the whips to mention this—not to make an accusation, but to remind people that this would not be an appropriate form of action and that they should desist in future.

They can remove it from the hard drive, but there will still be evidence that it was there. We have copies of the receipts of the documents generated through this particular methodology. Really it is beyond the pale. Certainly if the Australian Taxation Office catches up with any members of parliament putting in these sorts of false claims—I assume it is for tax purposes, but I cannot be absolutely certain—then basically they could be charged with forging and uttering and a total breach of the tax act with all its knock-on consequences.

I do hope that this practice discontinues in future, that the word gets around the building that computers in the electoral office are not meant for this particular ingenious use and that taxpayers as a whole are not defrauded by people using them in such a way.

talk.start.para: —Thank you Senator Robert Ray for ceding me some time to speak because I did not have my name down to speak on the adjournment. I want to respond to some of the things that Senator O'Brien said. Before I do that, I feel I should respond to some of the things that you have said, Senator Ray. It is easy to come into this place and make accusations or suggestions about a wide variety of people without providing any evidence but, if you have that sort of information, I would have thought you should be giving it to the Federal Police, not to the Senate in an adjournment debate.

speech.para: Without naming names, you have talked about South Australian and Queensland Liberal members of parliament and this has cast a shadow over all members. It is all very well to say, `I'm not talking about you, Senator Ferguson,' but I have a number of colleagues in this place. If you have this sort of information, rather than coming into the chamber on the adjournment debate and spreading a smear over all of my colleagues from South Australia, I would have thought you should provide that evidence to the Federal Police. That is the place it should be, rather than here in the Senate. It disturbs me that this chamber is used for this sort of general accusation rather than making specific accusations with some evidence.

talk.start.para: —Didn't you hear the same thing about Labor?
—I have heard lots of things about the Labor Party, but I would not raise them in the adjournment debate at 10.20 at night.
—You wouldn't have time!

—I only have nine or 10 minutes. Senator Ray, thank you for allowing me to do this. I want to respond to a couple of the things that Senator O'Brien said. This has been, in Senator O'Brien's eyes, a long running saga and I would say that I would have to give him 10 out of 10 for persistence and nought out of 10 for substance.

speech.para: In the estimates committee, we spent hours while Senator O'Brien trawled over this particular area of the Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business when he asked questions of Mr Gillespie for a considerable period.

It does not matter what answers are actually given in estimates; you can, if you want to, put your own interpretation on those answers which may differ from the interpretation that is put on them by either members on this side or from the intent of the answers that were given by people from the department. Not only did Senator O'Brien have the chance to question the officer concerned at length in estimates; he was also given an additional chance today to re-question the officer whom he requested be brought forward before a supplementary additional estimates hearing because he claimed in a letter to the clerk that he had been mislead. He said that there were only two options open to him: one to recall the estimates committee or to bring the matter to the Privileges Committee. I have seen the workload that Senator Ray has as Chairman of the Privileges Committee and I thought, in order to save him a little bit of time, that the best thing we could do is recall estimates first to give Senator O'Brien a chance to question this officer at length once more.

Having sat through that hearing this morning, I did remark to one of my colleagues that it was a bit like going to the dentist expecting to have a filling and finding they were still using the slow moving drill, because the same question was asked over and over again, the same answers were given over and over again. In fact, as far as I am concerned, Mr Gillespie gave his interpretation of what he intended his answers to be. This was not accepted by Senator O'Brien and so he, within his own rights, pursued the matter further.

Senator O'Brien used certain terms tonight such as `I find it hard to believe' when referring to certain meetings that took place. He might find it hard to believe but that does not necessarily mean that that the officer had not answered truthfully in estimates and had not given him all the information that he was required to do. He made comments in his speech such as `I assume Mr Feeney and Mr Bills. . . ', naming two people.

Then he accused Mr Gillespie of amending advice that was given to the government. Senator O'Brien, you were told in estimates this morning that when it comes to matters of departmental advice to ministers and to the government on strategy that advice is entitled to be treated as confidential. You were told that today. So you used words like `He amended the advice'. That is quite possible.

You then said things like, `I have been further advised.' I invited you at the meeting this morning to say where you had received your advice from, because it certainly did not come from the department. You might as well say, Senator O'Brien, `I have listened to rumours'. If you are not prepared to name the advice, say, `I have listened to rumours'. And if you refuse to give any credible sources of your advice, then I think it can justifiably be said that you are putting your own interpretation on answers that were given by departmental officers—not on one occasion but on two and three occasions on which they truthfully answered the questions that were put to them as far as their department was concerned, and that was confirmed by the other officers in the department.

You have a right to interpret those answers in any way you see fit, but to suggest that there was a misleading of the Senate only shows that, with time and further experience on estimates committees, you will ask other questions which might be perhaps more probing in getting a detailed response. You will find that departmental officers are giving you the replies that they feel they can officially give, especially when you consider that their role is not only giving answers to you but one of responsibility to the government. You suggested that Mr Gillespie refused to answer certain questions, and he said, `I am not in a position to answer those questions, because they are advice to government.' Tonight is the third or fourth occasion you have repeated some of the transcript of the estimates. Anybody reading the Hansard would know that those same questions were asked at estimates and that they were raised even at the estimates in August last year.

You have suggested that there is a lot more to come yet, but as committee chairman I felt obliged to give you every opportunity to ask Mr Gillespie any further questions that you wanted to ask him on any matter. I think that is a process of the Senate that you are entitled to use. I was very happy that we re-called the estimates committee to give you a chance to do that, because I do not honestly believe that every single case where a senator feels that he may have been misled in an answer should automatically go to Privileges Committee. I think it is important that you had the opportunity to once again question Mr Gillespie through the estimates procedure.

You had that opportunity. While you may feel from the answers that were given to you that the questions have not been fully answered, or you may feel that you were not told the full truth, that is only an interpretation on your part. I do not share that interpretation, having sat through hours of estimates committees earlier this year, for another hour this morning and through the August estimates last year. I would have thought that if you wanted to pursue this matter the best thing for you to do would be to wait until we have further estimates committees. The decision is entirely up to you, but I would have thought that you have had a greater opportunity than usual as an individual senator to pursue this matter. I can only repeat what I said before: if you did not get the answers you wanted, that is not the fault of the officer, nor is it the fault of the department; it is possibly the fault of your own perception of what you had hoped to receive in the way of answers that did not come.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 5 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Will a representative from Environment Australia be attending the Intercessional Meeting of the Technical Consultation on Monitoring Control and Surveillance Issues, in Suva, from 10-13 March 1998, as part of the development of a regional agreement for highly migratory fish stocks of the central and western Pacific; if not, why not.

(2) Will a representative from Environment Australia attend all subsequent technical and negotiating sessions, as a member of an official delegation, until the agreement has been finalised; if not, why not.

(3) Can an outline be provided of the efforts which will be made to ensure that the agreement fully recognises the need for ecologically sustainable fisheries management that takes into account the issue of ecologically related species (by catch) within the region in question.
(4) What efforts will be made to provide technical and financial help to small South Pacific states to effectively implement this Convention within the region once the agreement has been finalised.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) A representative from Environment Australia did not attend the Intercessional Meeting of the Technical Consultation on Monitoring, Control and Surveillance Issues, held in Suva, from 10-13 March 1998.

Fisheries monitoring, control and surveillance are standard fisheries management activities and are matters within the responsibilities of my colleague the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator the Honourable Warwick Parer. These matters are more appropriately dealt with by members of Senator Parer's portfolio.

(2) I would not expect Environment Australia to attend all of the technical and negotiating sessions until the agreement has been finalised. representation at all meetings would have significant resource implications for my Department, and some of these meetings deal with issues outside the responsibilities of my Department. However, I would expect my Department to take its place in the delegation for key negotiating sessions, and relevant technical meetings.

I am confident that Environment Australia's interests can be fully represented by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade if an Environment Australia representative is unable to attend any meeting. Environment Australia will play an active role in this issue, particularly with respect to matters relating to sustainable harvesting and impacts on ecologically related species. My Department will be involved in developing Australia's policy approach on this issue and in drafting the negotiating brief for Australia's official delegations.

(3) Environment Australia's active participation in all future developments relating to this issue will ensure that the final agreement fully recognises the need for ecologically sustainable fisheries management.
As I mentioned in answer to the previous question, Environment Australia will:
- be actively involved in the development of all policy relating to this issue
- be actively involved in the drafting of negotiating briefs for Australian delegations
- attend relevant technical meetings and negotiating sessions where resources allow.
If resources do not allow Environment Australia to attend these meetings, it will ensure that its interests are fully represented by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

(4) The information sought by the honourable senator does not fall within my Portfolio responsibilities. I suggest that she direct this question to my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Honourable Alexander Downer MP, who has overall responsibility for AusAID.
